description:
I usually get the bun (vermicelli bowls) here, and #40 offers a choice of beef, chicken & pork w/two cha gio (fried imperial rolls). 

The meat comes out freshly grilled, and the rolls are fried to order. Perfect with the cool veggies, pickles, and the ample amount of noodles.

Big hefty bowl of dipping sauce as well.

Small space, but plenty of seating, especially if you don't mind sharing a table.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Hate to do this. Your closed and you're supposed to be open right now. Three of us are outside but your doors are chained.

Fail.
author: Offset M.

description:
Super lovely and friendly people, but not my favorite noodle place in Chinatown. Their flavors for pho are just a tiny bit off.

A bit extra unlucky as I found a cockroach crawling around the chopstick container. The owners were very apologetic and good about it - but tipped this to two stars for me.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
Chinatown has three Golden restaurants all within a five-minute walking distance from each other. I mean there is the Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant, Golden King Vietnamese Restaurant and the Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant all close to each other. By sheer chance I happened to try Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant first from the lot. It is located on Grant and Jackson so right in the middle of the tourist circuit. At the peak lunch hour on a Saturday it was about 40% full. Like other Vietnamese restaurants it has a trillion variations of Pho, bun and rice plates. I decided to get the Five spice chicken ($8.75) to-go.

After ordering I waited for about 10 minutes at one of the open tables and then was off with my order. While paying I was surprised that I could pay by card which is very out of charter in Chinatown. I got a small size container with the Five spice chicken that was almost hidden under the serving of rice and two smaller containers with dipping sauce. The chicken and rice were both pretty good while the dipping sauce was terrific. Overall this was pretty good.

After the good experience I came back to try the Five spice chicken noodle soup ($10.75) which is noodle soup plus the five-spice chicken. This time I found the noodles to be a little clumped together but they managed to open up when dipped in the broth. Overall not bad. During my third visit I decided to get the Chicken with lemongrass ($10.25) from the Dinner Special section of the menu. This time it was a disaster a small serving of rock hard pieces of chicken with over steamed rice.

Price wise it was pretty cheap and in-line with what you would pay at other Golden restaurants in Chinatown. My take is that they have the batch produced items like Pho and five spice chicken locked down but what needs to be cooked to order the kitchen surely falters. Considering the overall package of quality, price, service I feel that this is a 3.5-star type of place so I'm rounding that up to 4.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Shot into here recently to try some pho since it's been relatively cold recently (I know not for our East Coasters). 

Ordered my combo pho and while it was good , there wasn't anything that stood out about it either.

Since so many pho spots taste similar there are without a doubt some that are way better and some that are way worse. For those in the "middle" of the pack  often times the thing that differentiates them is the service you get.

At this place the service felt very indifferent the afternoon I popped in. At many pho places even the busy ones with one savvy waitress/waiter they'll ask you what you want to drink. At this venue not a peep nor a follow up of how things were going. 

Maybe chalk it up to a bad/busy day?  

The world needs a SF Bay Area Pho Rankings...so I'm here to provide my humble list/rankings.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen , Chicken and Waffles as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places.

author: Rod M.

description:
Decent Vietnamese food in the SF Chinatown area.

Pho is served in three different bowl sizes. The broth is very clean and there is a good amount of protein and noodles served. If you are looking for a rich hearty broth to go with your noodles, Golden Flower is not the restaurant to come here for. 

Restaurant is maintained properly, the tables and floor are clean here. The ladies who run the place are absolutely very friendly too.
author: Philip M.

description:
The first time I came here was because they were serving #1 (beef combo pho) on MealPal... I keep coming back because this place is soooooo good. It's a block away from Golden Star, which my friend had taken me to before and all my coworkers seem to love, but Golden Flower is 200x better. I come during lunch time and there are generally seats open. Once you order, your food is there within 5 minutes. I generally never drink the broth anywhere when I eat noodle soup, but I swallow the whole thing when I come to Golden Flower. The piping warm broth is so satisfying on a cold winter day and it's not overly salty like other places.

Their noodle bowls come in small, medium, or large and served at different price points. Even the small is plenty of food but I generally go for the medium.

The restaurant is run by a couple of Asian ladies that speak English, Cantonese and Vietnamese. They are all super nice and attentive without overbearing. 

They also have banh xeo!!! 

The best part - they take credit card (but it's $10 and up)
author: Judy H.

description: Great warm homie feel. One of the few delicious pho restaurants in the chinatown area. Owners are really nice and welcoming. Usually packed on prime lunch and dinner hours. I love their imperial rolls! Not much places make it like them! Also, their pho broth is on the clearer side and really tasty. Order anything here and you are set! Enjoy
author: Peter R.

description:
After countless visit, this place is starting to let me down. Ordered a bun bo hue and they used different noodles (should be thicker) and they really skimp on the meat. The soup was still very good but other components lacked

The pros to this place is it takes credit cards and usually no wait compared to another vietnamese restaurant
author: Henry T.

description:
Be wary if you are doing online orders - the prices on postmates / ubereats are supremely low on paper. 

Once you check-out the amount will sky rocket; typical bait and switch.

Food is whatever to me - if the food was actually priced what they are shown online, then you get what you pay for. 

I would just stay away from doing delivery orders from here... you'll thank me later.
author: Sam K.

description:
I had the vermicelli noodles with bbq pork and it was decent. It came with plenty of noodles and the bbq pork was cooked pretty well but it lacked anything really special about the dish. It was more of a standard faire kind of restaurant.

They did give plenty of fish sauce which was nice but that was a little plain as well. There veggies were mostly limited to just the salad and bean sprouts, it would have been a bit nicer if they had more fresh herbs.
author: Tyler T.

description:
I don't know why they became greedy now. One large bowl of beef noodles $10 "inside got 2 slice of beef and 2 meat balls, 1 slice of beef tender. Some noodle" that it. For $11 

NOT WORTH
author: Jackson L.

description: My go to spot when I have to travel to work around Chinatown area. I love the BBQ pork pho to go along with a soy milk. Pro-quick service, friendly owner who remembers me even after 6 months of not coming by, delicious food. I love that they fill the pho broth halfway in the to go container as once I add the noodles, the volume is perfect. Cons-I have dined in once and the trays that they hold their chop sticks and soup spoons look really dirty.
author: Annie L.

description:
Pho was good. However, it could have been better. 

Ordered the Xe Lua pho. Pho came in around 10 minutes. 

The pho.... 
- Noodles were good a decent amount. 
- Meats were a generous amount but was mostly fat. The brisket was the most delicious part out of the entire pho. 
- Broth? If I had to choose, I'd choose Golden King over Golden Flower. Golden King's broth just feels more genuine. 
- You had the option to choose S/M/L or XL in some cases. Which gives me more choice. 

The service... 
- Pretty fast and descent. 
- Accepts credit cards! Nice! But only Visa and Master. If you have Discover or Amex, They will reject it. 

Overall, Not bad. But could be better.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Golden Flower - not to be mistaken for golden star down the street.  I always order the vegetarian spring rolls here!  It's an amazing deal - you get 4 huge rolls (well, 2 cut in half) with peanut sauce for $7.50!  It really doesn't get much better than that.  And these are quality rolls, not like the ones you'd get wrapped in syran at Trader Joes.

All my coworkers love getting the pho here and claim that the broth is better than the neighboring competitors.  They're super generous with the portions, and you will NEVER leave hungry!  Other popular dishes include the 5 spice chicken and vermicelli bowl.

Complimentary tea for the table (leave the pot open when it's empty and they'll refill it for you), decent service (for Chinatown), and plenty of seating.  You can order takeout if you want, but be prepared to wait a bit.  The takeout pho will definitely require a massive soup bowl, so be prepared if you're taking this back to the office.

They prefer if you don't use a card for charges under $10, but if you have nothing else they'll do it for you.  There is a bit of a lunchtime rush but they typically always have seats available.  This is definitely a spot worth coming to if you're in the mood for good Vietnamese food!
author: Kenna H.

description:
One day, I came down with a cold and sore throat and decided to nurse it with some pho. Or maybe I decided to use the cold as an excuse to get some pho. Either way, I came into the store at night and it was a quiet weekday evening with few customers inside. I was promptly seated and perused the menu, even though I came in determined to get some variation of the beef pho. However, I let my eyes wander and thought wouldn't it be nice to have some pho ga (chicken noodle soup) for a change? I gave in to my curiosity since I haven't had chicken pho in such a long time. 

My pho came out within five minutes of my ordering it. I proceeded to savor the broth and then unceremoniously poured all my veggies into the pho. The pho ga (chicken noodle soup) was very delicious, and flavorful compared to other places. The broth was very clear, and there is a beautiful golden glow glistening as you can see in the picture below. I finished the soup and the noodles and left the meal fully satiated. Now, I'm not saying that I was cured by some chicken pho, but during the meal, I certainly felt a lot better. For ten dollars, this was deeply satisfying and left me feeling very full, which was a good thing since I had to brave the winds as I left the store. I'll remember to come back for the pho ga the next time I have a cold.
author: Nelson X.

description: Poor customer service, we are the entire meal before water was offered to us. What kind of restaurant will watch you eat before offering basic water. The old lady moved so slow, and the daughter was just chatting it up with friend. The food tasted marginal at best. Absolute lack of professionalism. I WILL NOT BE BACK.
author: Daniel A.

description: Stopped by for lunch, not a bad place.  We ordered the spring rolls for our appetizer, parents got the pho, the bro got the papaya salad, and I got the rice platter with grilled pork.  The spring rolls came out medium hot, rice platter was delicious, the meat had flavor to it.  Service was quick.
author: Phuong O.

description: We were tired of Chinese food so we found this pearl right on one of the side streets of China town. Pho was absolutely delicious and fresh. I had the veggie crispy fried noodles. Loved it. Add a side of freshly squeezed lime aid and hot tea. Just what we needed after a long day in China town!! Great service, happy people. We'll be back.
author: Crowlynn M.

description:
I came here about 3 months ago for a reunion lunch with my former co-workers and it's my go to Vietnamese restaurant now!

I have been taking my friends here and they  really like it too! Their imperial rolls are my favorite! My go to dish is #40 Bun Cha Gio, Heo (Flame Broiled Pork) it's my favorite!! It comes with imperial rolls! I usually eat the whole bowl because it's so delicious!

My friends have ordered their Pho and rice plates and they like their meals, too.

The lighting in the restaurant is kinda dim so I can't take pictures of my favorite dish :-(
author: Allie L.

description:
Pretty amazing spot for mid day quick lunch pho fix. Prices are amazing, service is quick, and they take credit card (this is a rarity in Chinatown!). 

The tables and chairs are a bit sticky but eh. They're moving patrons in and out so fast that I understand it's not going to be sparkling clean.
author: Ming Y.

description:
I have been several Vietnamese Restaurants in the past but in the years that I have lived in San Francisco.... This was my very 1st time ever that I ate lunch at the Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant... Which was in the San Francisco Chinatown area and I have past by this Vietnamese Restaurant so many times and never thought that... 

I would have lunch at the Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant until today I had decided that I wanted to come here and just have some lunch at this Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant on my day off from work!!! 

When I got inside in the beginning and as I greeted by the friendly hostess who took me to my table it wasn't that crowded yet and what I ordered for myself was a Shrimp & Pork Fried Rice!!! Overall after finishing it all in which I was really hungry!!! I have to say that the Shrimp & Pork Fried Rice that I ate for my very 1st for lunch tasted really good!!!

I definitely would wanna go back to the Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant at another time and try something different!!!
author: William B.

description: Was recommended to me on my trip to San Fran and I wasn't disappointed.  I had the spring rolls and the rare beef pho and they were delicious.  The place is as you expect, its tight with no frills but it didn't matter.  Service was good, great on a cold and rainy San Francisco day!
author: Carla F.

description:
Pho in Chinatown, because why not?  It hit the spot on a rainy day, but it's really not something to make a special trip out of your way for.  There are much better options in Little Saigon, but it was still decent.

Extra Large Pho: The most noticeable aspect were the HUGE meatballs.  I suspect most places halve or quarter their meatballs, but it was the whole thing here.  Like 3-4 bites per meatball.  I skipped the tendon and tripe (since I'm not into the slimy/chewy texture) but enjoyed all the other meats.  Overall, the meat portion seemed a tad smaller than other "Extra Large" bowls around town.  The noodles were al dente and just the right portion for me.  They put in tons of broth compared to the noodles, which is exactly how I like it.  The broth itself was ok, but I've definitely had better elsewhere (e.g. Bodega Bistro, Pho 2000).
author: Adam B.

description:
Pros: good food
They take credit card
Owner is very nice

Cons: gotta walk up Chinatown (not really a con if you need exercise)

I do prefer their lunch plates over the pho here but they're both good.
author: Jason T.

description: I'm used to not getting great service at Vietnamese restaurants, but it was extraordinarily bad here. To top that, it was the blandest pho I've had in my life. The prices were cheap: $7.95 for a small, but it was huge. They give you plenty of meat, but the broth had absolutely no flavor. The hoisin sauce is thinned out, and no matter how much I doused in my pho, it didn't help. There are so many better places in town.
author: Ha D.

description:
Quality of the pho (broth and amount of contents) has slipped just a bit on my last two visits, since Golden Flower was apparently discovered by a source that now sends a lot of non-Asian diners. 

It's still very, very good but no longer destination pho. Which is actually quite liberating because if you have another favorite pho place, now you don't have to make a special trip to Chinatown.
author: Otis M.

description:
I had the Lemongrass Chicken, but it consisted of only onion slices and chicken, and without any lemongrass flavor that I could detect.

So, while it was decent, it didn't seem to live up to its name.

Service was attentive and the prices are $1-2 lower than all the others nearby,
author: Some Bozo ..

description:
This hole in the wall restaurant is not only an excellent Vietnamese noodle joint, but also makes for your money's worth. It is a must visit if you're a fan of a delicious bowl of piping hot Pho noodle soup cooked without the dreaded MSG. The food is reasonably priced and the cheapest bowl of Pho goes for about $7 dollars. Moreover, the portions are generous (the large bowl is twice my face) and the quality justifies the price. Other highlights on the menu include a fragrant flame broiled lemongrass beef, crisped deep fried golden imperial rolls and perfectly flavored shrimp sticks that only creates an umami experience. Their cooking never fails to hit the spot, no wonder this place is attracts so many people. Also, the restaurant features a huge variety of vegetarian meals as well as popular Chinese dishes- it's like a one stop shop for all! 

The longstanding popularity (15 years) of this place is partly thanks to its location: one that is easy to stumble upon in the heart of San Francisco aka Chinatown. It's blue themed décor and stand out signage catches ones eye in the fortune cookie stricken part of the city. The restaurant is a great option for a quick solo lunch or communal blow-out with the mates (longest table fits 12 people). It's a great place to go when you're hungry as the dishes come out at the speed of light. Furthermore, the service is faultless. The staff is extremely attentive, meanwhile, the owner of this place is extremely friendly which makes the environment feel more homely and further enhances the dining experience. She will remember you and will remember any of your special requests, even if you've only visited once. Let me tell you, Golden Flower is the REAL DEAL.
author: Jeanne L.

description: The ladies here are super nice. Food was great! Prices are super reasonable for a good quantity. We also had sweet and sour chicken which was yummy. Pho was awesome . We had a good time. The restaurant is nice and seems private. I left full and happy. Thank You
author: Sean V.

description:
There's a few pho places around the area but I have been going to this one a lot more since it is a bit of a walk. The distance help, if you ate a big bowl of pho and need to stay awake in the office...

+Quick service
+Quick staff
+Quick food turnover

Can be a bit of a wait during rush hour but if I'm not in a hurry I will definitely wait.
author: Sam Y.

description: I really loved this restaurant! My favorite Vietnamese dish is catfish in a claypot and they prepared it very well. It was truly delicious. We are visiting from South Texas and Minnesota and found this place to be cozy and special. The owner was exceptionally friendly and made us feel like close friends. Hopefully we will try it again...GREAT!! Miguel/Gator
author: Miguel J.

description: Best pho I've had in the city! We stopped by around 1 PM and it was empty, we sat down anyway and ordered. By the time our food came out, the place was packed! I had pho tai nam and my wife had seafood pho. We also got eggrolls and Vietnamese iced coffee & milk. Delicious all around, and the staff was professional and very nice. Stop by this place if you're in the area, you won't regret it!
author: Will T.

description:
I ended up at this restaurant after not being served at another pho place around the corner. I was single and was sat down and served right away. There was only a couple there with a child. 

I ordered a simple pho and it arrived quickly, was good and I was happy to leave a very good tip.

The decor was a little dated, the young waitress was paying more attention to her phone, but that was fine, there was nobody else there. Otherwise a nice warm pho on a cool night did the trick.
author: Ben N.

description: Amazing food awesome service ,  small cosy place . The best Vietnamese food I have tried.
author: Samira D.

description: I came here because they take credit card (vs golden star which is cash only). I got the rare beef pho. The small size is still big and has plenty of noodles and beef. The broth is nothing special. It was quick and warm lunch. It was total of $8.45 which is a good price.
author: Christie W.

description: The place has sort of a family-run restaurant feel to it. It's small, but service was fast. I ordered the rare beef pho (small size), which was ~$7.75. There was surprisingly a lot of noodle and meat, a pleasant surprise really. The broth however was a bit flat and isn't as rich. It was still tasty though, after adding some sauces.
author: Adrian S.

description: The pho here is good and the rare beef dish is one of my favorites but what makes this place better than most is the service and the cleanliness.  Prices are reasonable and the value is there.  My neighborhood pho joint for sure.
author: Patrick C.

description: Had the worst dining experience from Golden Flower. I came in with my friend around noon time. I ordered a small bowl of pho and on my fourth bite, I noticed a FLY inside. I told the worker about it and she wasn't apologetic and had a very unprofessional attitude towards the problem. Clearly the problem was in the kitchen but she tried to deny it and make up some bullshit to cover the restaurant flaws. After the confrontation, my friend who was still in the middle of eating, another worker just went up to our table and puts the check on it when we didn't even request to check out. At this point, we were fed up with the unprofessional service so we paid and left. NOT COMING HERE EVER AGAIN.
author: Rose T.

description:
Golden Flower is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the neighborhood, and for a while I was eating there at least once a week for lunch. It's also my go-to spot for a quick and easy dinner close to home. The space itself isn't anything special; in fact, when it's super busy it feels really cramped and it's hard to navigate past tables. But the woman who runs the restaurant is an absolute doll and the food is consistently delicious. 

My favorite dishes are the shrimp and pork roll (their peanut sauce is addicting), the imperial rolls (crispy and full of flavor), the rare steak beef pho (their broth heals all ailments), and the five spice chicken rice plate with an egg (hearty portion and chicken is perfectly cooked). Really you can't go wrong with anything you order from there. The small pho is the perfect size; any larger and you'd have to roll me out of there. The pho comes with a large plate of add-ins, like thai basil, jalapeno and lime. 

Final notes: Service is a bit lacking (the servers are not the friendliest), but food is delivered quickly and efficiently. Do yourself a favor and don't use their restroom. If you love noodles, this place will quickly become one of your favorite spots.
author: Regina L.

description: It seemed like locals go there often. It was very busy when we visited. The chicken/mushroom/rice plate I had was great.
author: Michal G.

description: Came here with Nate and Chad and had the phone love phone eat phone whenever I can best phone I have had ever maybe next time I will come back here and eat more phone
author: Heywood J.

description: Stopped in here on vacation on a whim and so glad I did!!!  Rare steak pho was delicious and small portion goes a LONG way. Very friendly staff and fast service.  I will definitely put this on my go to list!
author: Lisa M.

description:
An average Viet eatery (doesn't necessarily mean bad) with many of the same menu items you can find elsewhere. The fact that they open later than many places - and in Chinatown at that - gave them a better than average grade.

Their Bun Bo Hue is how I like it - oily and full of flavors - I would return just for it. The Imperial Rolls is good as well but that's because I like fried rolls with rice paper instead of egg wrappers used for egg rolls and wonton. Friends liked their pho but I thought it was just like anywhere else. The Bun Thit Nuong is good, not outstanding.

The place feels like a noodle house, more than a restaurant so it's very casual. Tables are for two or four with a large central group table if needed. The restroom is passed the cash register and down one level of narrow stairs.
author: Peter L.

description: Loved this place.  Great pho, and could definitely tell we were in the right place in China Town because we were only customers that spoke English.  Staff was attentive, spoke English, and delivered tasty food quickly.
author: Scott R.

description:
A group of us were nearby around Union Square and decided to walked into Chinatown for dinner on Wednesday, October 7th around 8:45pm. We were a group of 4 and easily grabbed a table.

Pho: beef noodle soup ($6.70 small, $7.30 medium, $7.85 large)
1. Xe lua (extra large): special combo with rare slices of steak, well-done brisket, flank, tendon, tripe & beef balls
10. Tai chin: rare steak with brisket

23. Cha gio: egg rolls ($6.40)
48. Com ga ngu vi huong & cha gio: five spice chicken with imperial rolls ($8.95)

I got the #1. I'm not sure if I got to pick the size since it says extra large by the description, but it looked the same size as the #10 we got which was a large. The #1 had good variety of meats and toppings. And a lot of soup! I love drinking the soup, so this was perfect for me. We all shared the imperial rolls. A good portion as I think we got 6 of them. And they gave us rice paper to make rolls as well.

Nice option for pho in Chinatown. I work in downtown, so it's nice to know Golden Flower is close by.
author: Elena N.

description:
First time trying this place and had thier #1 pho and #91 Bun bo hue. 

I'm a visitor to the city and saw the high ratings and good reviews here, so I made it a point to get some real good Viet food before I fly home.

Was sorely disappointed.

I'm Vietnamese and grew up eating Viet food. I can say without a doubt that this is not the place to experience good Vietnamese food in San Francisco. 

Good:
- Service was quick and efficient
- Portions are large for the prices

Bad:
- THE PHO BROTH IS LOADED WITH MSG. The type where you're extremely thirsty after your meal and have a dry mouth. I ate here about 3 hours ago and still feel this way. 

- Bun Bo Hue lacked a lot of flavour - basically bland water soup with no spiciness. Doesn't have all the meats that usually comes with this type of soup noodle. And to top that all off, they used the WRONG noodles (vermicelli noodles) instead of the thick round noodles normally in this! Couldn't finish it.

-They water down their Hoisin sauce condiment!! It was absolutely disgusting to know they fool around with the sauce to save on cost. It made dipping my meats difficult and so I had to resort to POURING the sauce from the dipping plate onto my meat.
author: Ethan N.

description: So we were staying at the Hilton right around the corner. I placed an order to go for Tai Pho, and was pleasantly surprised about the quality and quantity of what was included with each order. The reason for the 4 star rating was about the price versus the soup ordered. When I looked online and it was listed at one price and when I went to pick up was given a differant total.
author: James S.

description: I love this place (probably too much). I come in and they don't even ask me for my order any more, they just say "the usual?" Its great. The people who work here are so kind and clearly work very hard. The #5 is what I normally get. The broth is delicious and I always ask for 5 limes (I'm weird) and they never question me. :)
author: Kelli N.

description: Pretty decent vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown. I enjoyed my pho although it wasn't amazing. The beef tartare was delicious. They even have banh xeo! I like the variety especially since not every place serves every vietnamese dish like banh xeo. The price is pretty decent too.
author: Jenn T.

description:
We loved the Imperial Roll and the Ginger Chicken a lot. Dipping sauce very nice too. The 
Lemongrass Chicken is a hot dish for you fire breathers, but needs more  lemongrass and fewer onions. Waitstaff speaks both Chinese and English fluently, and are both polite and kind. Prices good. Good portion size too.
author: Susan M.

description:
This place started my pho career. I use to come here so often but I haven't had the chance to until I came here for lunch today with a couple of friends who worked nearby.

At 12pm on a weekday, the place is pretty much packed. People who worked near by were coming in and out so there was no wait in line.

I like how they offer "only tendons" with pho on their menu. Honestly, tendons are my favorite part of the pho and other restaurants don't have this option on their menu unless you request it. We know the food is fresh since our food came out about 15 mins after we ordered. At other pho places, they come within 5 mins when all they had to do is dump noodles and other goodies in a bowl with broth.

I ordered a small for $6.70 which is enough for me for lunch during work hours since I wouldn't want to go back to work all bloated. However, my friends(guys) who ordered a large size says it wasn't enough for them. Each size up is less than a dollar more so don't be afraid to order a bigger size if you are really hungry.The soup was a little watered down I had to add extra herbs to create extra flavor for my liking. For the rest of the day, I had to drink a lot of water to quench my thirst which is probably from the extra MSG in their broth. Although it's not the best broth I had, the rice noodles were good. It was soft and smooth.

The service is pretty quick. They seat you immediately and take your order within minutes. All the workers were pacing back and forth.

Overall, I would come back to grab a quick sit-down meal. This is a place for casualty, cheap food, and quick service.
author: Allie Y.

description: Such great service here. Really friendly family who took care of us on a Sunday. Delicious pho, goi cun, spring rolls. And a lovely 3 bean drink the kids loved.
author: Anne F.

description:
It was early in the evening on Jackson Street, in San Francisco's Chinatown, when I took the photograph which accompanies this review. Chinatown is a wonderful place, full of hustle, bustle and more intrigue than a John le Carré spy novel.

You can get whatever you want in Chinatown, so be careful about what you want.

Fortunately, all Vesta and I wanted was to find what we heard was the best Vietnamese restaurant this side of Saigon. We know it's Ho Chi Minh City now, but the guy we met at one of the Camera stores on the Wharf, who told us, was getting up there in his years and apparently he hadn't heard about the name change, though they did it an awful long time ago.

Anyway, he told us about this Vietnamese Restaurant on Jackson Street in Chinatown, that was so very good and the way he described it, we just had to go. Unfortunately, he didn't know the name of it, but he said we'd be able to find it.

After we found a parking spot and fed the meter, I took a photograph, then we started looking. And the guy was right, it took us about thirty seconds to find it. Actually, if you look at the far right side of my photograph, you can see the Golden Flower's blue sign.

At first we weren't gonna go in, because we were supposed to meet friends at Eat At Joe's back at the Wharf later for dinner. We just went looking for the restaurant cuz it was in Chinatown and we wanted to go there anyway and cuz it was like a challenge to see if we could find it.

But we did find it and we were there and maybe I was a tiny bit hungry, so we went in and had pho, a beefy noodle pho, which wasn't all that expensive and very, very tasty. And maybe even more than we should've eaten, considering our dinner plans.

It was a nice dining experience. The pho was delightful and we'll be back when we can don't have dinner plans for later and we can eat more and more and more.
author: Ken D.

description: It was so hard to flag down someone down.  I had to keep flagging them down because I drank so much water.  The food was fresh and I ordered what I wanted.  Even though i didn't speak Chinese it was helpful to look at pictures to order.
author: Jenifer H.

description: Ordered to-go lemon grass shrimp and was expecting some combination of main, vegetables,  and starch. Instead, what I received was just a mix of shrimp with onions and rice( more rice than shrimp of course)... for $10.50. Oh and one ghost shrimp( just the tail and no prawn). Never again.
author: Masya A.

description:
A place that I frequent - one of the better pho restaurants in the Nob Hill/Chinatown area. Prices are very reasonable at $~8-9 for a large bowl of pho. The broth is very top notch also - my typical go to is #1 since it comprises the most meats.

The imperial rolls here are also absolutely delicious with the duck sauce. View my pictures to see!
author: Albert K.

description:
Dropped in on a Monday afternoon and ordered a small bowl of Pho along with a Viet iced coffee. 
Overall, the noodles wasn't bad but the iced coffee was overfilled with ice.

When it came to the billing, I realized they had charged me for a medium Pho instead of a small. When I brought it up to the waitress, she simply responded that "the prices have gone up". Hmm, then how come the menu still stated with the old prices? A bit sketchy, eh? Maybe it would be a good idea to update your menu or at least inform your customers in advance if prices increased to prevent any misunderstandings.
author: Minnie C.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown. I've been coming here for a long time with my family. 

I always get the Goi Cuong (spring rolls), and the Bun Tom Thit Nuong (grilled pork vermicelli bowl with grilled shrimp). It's my favorite. And the Com Thit Nuong (grilled pork over rice).

The restaurant is kind of cramped. It's always busy during the lunch hour. The restroom is down a steep stairway and it's kind of dirty. 
It reminds me of a dungeon. But this Is San Francisco, most of the restaurants in Chinatown are old. 

The service is good. They are pretty fast. The food is very good. It keeps me coming back for more.
author: Edie G.

description:
Party of 7. We went peak time during lunch around noon. We were seated immediately. Very nice and friendly service. Good took a while to arrive but it was completely worth the wait because it came hot and sizzling. Me being a recent vegetarian came here specially for their vegetable noodle soup and it was everything I had imagined it to be. Def going to come back soon! 
Vegetable noodle soup (veggie pho) small $7 !!!!
author: Arshi K.

description:
I'm a regular here. Cheap, delicious pho. Need I say more? 

 I even take friends from out of town. They all love it. I will say the chicken is better than the seafood.
author: Matt F.

description: Best vegetarian pho in SF! Super friendly staff, quick service. Always our go to spot!
author: Megan D.

description: Long overdue review! I used to work in the City and found this to be my favorite Pho restaurant.  I came here often, and they always remembered my order! I've moved jobs now for almost 5 years and every time I'm in the City, I come my pho fix here, AND they still remember my order! Great food for the awesome price!!
author: Ranjini D.

description:
I've read about the Golden Flower in a blog and they recommended the Pho, which is a noodle soup and the Vietnamese traditional dish. 
I've never tried that dish before, but I ordered a large Xe Lua, that is noodle soup with slices of steak, and I didn't know it was so large! If you're not really hungry, ask the small one!
The taste is very different from any other thing I've ever ate. Actually, I didn't like it very much, maybe because it's too different for me.
I didn't like the ambience of the restaurant either. The tables are like those folding metal tables, neither very comfortable nor pretty.  
The prices are cheap, though. You can have a small noodle soup and a soda for less than 10 dollars, including tip.
author: Amanda B.

description: Recommend by the locals for Pho. Very flavorful broth and meat. Fixins were just what I like. Very friendly staff.
author: Bob A.

description: Terrible Pho. It's basically MSG + Water. So bland and tasteless. 2 stars is given for the pork chops, which is average and edible
author: Lân V.

description: Delicious food that smells great, tastes great, and looks amazing. I had the bun and the beef was well cooked. Their sauce for their salad roll is next to none. People with a Peanut allergy beware!
author: Winston L.

description: My favorite go to pho spot in Chinatown! I always get the usual number 1 large. The workers here are super friendly and welcoming. It is usually busy here during the weekends in the afternoon but they still have good service! Only thing is that their hoisin sauce is a little watered down, not thick.. I don't really use it though because their broth for pho is pretty flavorful!
author: Linore R.

description: Best Pho in town!  Generous portions and delicious.  Super nice owner will take care of you.  I go to this place whenever I get a cold or want warm chicken pho.  Medium size is a solid meal for one.  I have only been here for takeout.
author: Mike J.

description: We are from out of state and was craving some good Pho. This little place was excellent. Two of us shared the large brisket Pho and our other party chose the beef chow Mein and chicken fried rice. It came out to $10 a person. The brisket was sliced thin and tender with fresh water, noodles, sprouts, fresh jalapeños and lime. Pour soy sauce, sweet brown sauce and hot sauce. Very rich and addicting. We will be coming back!
author: Rochelle N.

description:
Excellent food! My sister and Aunt are locals and this is their favorite Vietnamese place. It is somewhere I will make sure to stop at each visit because it is just that good!

I had #100 on the menu (prawn with bamboo shoots) with rice and it was great. My sister got a soup #98? (Sweet and sour soup) and that was really good too.
author: Bonnie P.

description: My elderly grandma wanted to take a couple more minutes to decide what to get and the waiter got angry that she was taking too long. Terrible service and would not recommend anyone to come.
author: Bobo H.

description: Have to drop by for quick launch it busy today took about 5 to 10 minutes for table  if you wanna come out to downtown don't bother traffic terrible have a nice day take care
author: Miko A.

description:
My favorite restaurant to go to when I had my layovers in San Francisco when working with the airlines. One of my copilots took me there a few years ago and I go back there every chance I get. The owners are great people and the service is excellent. 

Tony
Castle Rock, CO
author: Tony A.

description:
I came here to get my pho fix!  

F o o d

I ordered their rare steak slices, beef balls with vermicelli thin rice noodles and it was delicious!  Add Sriracha hot sauce and the pho bowl is bomb!  I couldn't ask for a more convenient place in Chinatown to fulfill my Pho craving!  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-flower-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gz0IDGDgYm0_fpH8dgFvdg#gz0IDGDgYm0_fpH8dgFvdg

Their rice plate with a sunny side egg on top and five spice chicken on the side is good.  The five spice chicken lacked more spices to enhance the flavor of it and a crispier texture, but it was still tender and yum!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-flower-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gz0IDGDgYm0_fpH8dgFvdg#t7n3yuneWFjNysZlJzBc2g

Their imperial rolls were pretty good!  It stands out in a way that it was the first time I had grounded taro with the mixture of pork in the imperial rolls!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-flower-vietnamese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=gz0IDGDgYm0_fpH8dgFvdg#RxkN8bxJ4gWOT7B-Z3KLnw

They offer a variety of stuff that you may want with your noodle soup or rice plate!  You can customize what you want and don't want upon ordering!

S e r v i c e 

The servers were attentive.  When we asked for more lemon wedges or basil, they got it for us quickly.

L a y o u t 

This restaurant is small compared to other pho places I have been to, which makes it a cozier place to be in!

F i n a l  S a y

I got my pho craving fulfilled!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Vegetarian Pho with Vegetarian broth! That, among other things, is why I love this place. Outside of that, the staff is friendly and the atmosphere is pleasant.

If you're looking for a quick, affordable, place for authentic food then this is your spot.
author: Tom A.

description:
Well just like the Koreans taking over Japantown, the Vietnamese are taking over Chinatown, just more slowly. 

This is the third Pho (pronounced Fa-uh) restaurant I have eaten at in Chinatown, and funny, they are all named Golden something. (That would be "Kim" something in Vietnamese)
And it is the 113th or 114th Pho Noodles restaurant I have eaten in and reviewed! (I lose count, there are so many!) Call me a Pho King Noodle expert! ("Low Fan", or "outsider" version though!)

This one benefits from being on the now busy lower Jackson street corridor in Chinatown. It's busy because Obama once ducked into the Great Eastern for Chinese food, and this has seemed to create a tourist frenzy that has spilled over to nearby establishments, even if they are Vietnamese. The fat tourists don't have to walk up the hills to Grant or Stockton on the verge of a heart attack to get here. And it is closer to FiDi.

It is narrow and long, with 3 rows of tables, quatres on the sides, community or quatres in the middle. The cashier counter is in the rear. 

I ordered Pho Tai Bo Vien, which is rare beef slices (Tai) with beef balls (Bo Vien). No, they weren't balls from cattle, they are little meatballs you can buy at any Ranch 99 market, and popular in Pho. 

The broth was pretty clear, a good sign that flavor was cooked in, not added artificially. Still, i like a little more hint of anise in my broth, and this had a little more sour taste than many. It came out quickly and the condiments were fresh. The noodles were al dente, which was different, because many places over cook them and they become mushy and milky. 

The owner is from Central Vietnam. She lived in Pleiku, Da Nang, Hue, and Nha Trang. Central Vietnam, or the Highlands region, is mountainous, cooler, and the food is spicier. Hue is the ancient capital near the old DMZ. Da Nang is popular with honeymooners due to cooler and pretty scenery. Pleiku was a US Air Base during the Vietnam war. Nha Trang (actually not quite central, more north part of South) is now a top tourist destination with a beautiful beach and a recent world beauty pageant held there. 

The signature noodle dish from Central is Bun Bo Hue, a hearty stew like, spicy noodle soup with just about everything thrown in. Since the owner is from Central, I would suggest trying the Bun Bo Hue if you like that dish.   

The fact that this and the other Viet places in Chinatown are all called Golden something gives a hint that, although from Vietnam, these people may be part of the large Chinese diaspora that resided in Vietnam. Most Vietnamese Vietnamese places are named after a city (like those mentioned above, or Saigon, Vung Tau, My Tho and many others) or after an important year in history, like Pho 54 (1954, the year a young general named Ho Chi Minh defeated the French at Dien Bien Phu), or after the Vietnamese family, like Vien Huong, Huynh Hiep, and many others. (This would be like Tony Roma's, etc.) 

The Vietnamese restaurants with names like Golden something in English, or Kim something something in Vietnamese (Pho Kim Long), are often Chinese-Vietnamese. They could be diaspora for generations, so it often doesn't show up in the food, and especially to the American or non-Vietnamese. But sometimes it does.

But perhaps they are called Golden something for the American tourists to remember, and for good luck. Most tourists from the midwest not exposed to Vietnamese food will still come into a restaurant like this looking for Chow Mien and fried rice. At least they can get egg rolls. (Cha Gio, pronounced Cha Yaw) and spring rolls (Goi Cuon, pronounced Goy Koon). 

Vietnamese, like Chinese, is a Tonal language, so getting the pronunciation is only half the battle. The tone of each word is critical to the meaning. Their are 6 ways to say "Ba" in Vietnamese, and depending on the tone, it means 6 different things.  

Although big brother to the north (China) has meddled with Vietnam through the ages, the Chinese in Vietnam were discriminated against as a minority, not unlike the other minorities in the region, like the Hmong, Mien, and others. In Saigon (Now Ho Chi Minh City), there was a specific large ghetto in the city called Cho Lon (still there) that is the Chinese district.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Hands down best pho in the area! The food is amazing and the owner is the sweetest lady who remembers every regular. Been going here for over a year and still best in my opinion! Love the family feel!
author: Dave E.

description:
This place is a sweet little restaurant with really nice workers. I got the vermicelli with grilled beef and egg rolls and it was a huge portion, since it was only one size. I managed to eat most of it and it was pretty delicious! The meat was very juicy and fresh, but the eggrolls were just mediocre in my opinion. Regardless it was still delicious!

My other family members got pho and the large size is humongous so I'd recommend sticking with the small size unless you're really hungry ;) 

Anyway, workers were nice, food was good, the only downside is that it's a little tightly packed inside, but definitely worth visiting and trying if you're craving Vietnamese food!
author: Vi D.

description:
Last Friday night, my party of five (plus our service dog) came in because the wonderful Z&Y Restaurant was filled. We were visiting from out of town with friends from SoCal after a long days walk and sightseeing.  I didnt want to pre-judge this hole-in-the-wall (from past experience these could be quite good). Despite cramped quarters, a good amount of people indicated possible good food. 
  However, bad things happened from the outset. As we got seated, the young waitress/hostess spoke in vietnamese to (I assume) the owner and then said our dog was not allowed in. I responded that he is a service dog as his vest indicated. She wanted to see his certification. I responded there is no such thing and by law she cannot ask me for that. She and the "owner" went back and forth in vietnamese. The "owner" appeared upset and walked away to the kitchen.
   Next, the bathroom and pathway to it was dirty, untidy, and in worrisome condition.
   Finally, it is important to note that our two kids dont eat like adults. So, we ordered 3 large Phô soups to share amongst us. The older lady (owner?) came and said that for 3 orders she wasnt willing to seat 5 ppl at a large table esp. becuz she was expecting possibly a party of 8 at some point. We shared that she could seat us at a table that seats 5 ppl. She didn't want to. I said we are paying customers that had hungry kids. She said she was sorry but she didn't want to serve us. I repeated that she could seat us at an appropriate table. Confused (or perturbed) she walked away saying she had to figure something out.
   My family and friends shared that they were uncomfortable there and were afraid what the restaurant would do to the food if we stayed. So, we left. Some people around us spoke to each other that it appeared that the real problem seemed to be that the restaurant didn't want a service animal in there restaurant. I wondered the same. 
   We will not be returning. I hope any person that supports service animals will not support this horrible place.
author: Alex N.

description:
Came here on New Years Day because every other Chinese restaurant in Chinatown was packed.

Price: CHEAP, like DAMNNNN cheap.

Food: Ok, this is the bad part, everything was very "meh" and trust me, I was hungry. I ordered their "extra large" number 1. The only thing I noticed was big was the bowl, the contents looked the same as my friend's mediums and smalls.

Would not return.
Also, if you're eating Pho in Chinatown, you're doing something wrong.
author: Da X.

description:
A little diamond in the ruff. We came to explore china town and started craving pho and asked a store owner of any places she recommended and she told us about the Golden Flower. 
Yummyyyyy! Best Thai tea I've had in a good while! The pho was great as well. I suggest to go hungry so you could finish the bowl. 
Next time we come to China town we'll come back:)
author: Stacy Z.

description:
I first discovered this place completely by accident, and am sure glad that I did. I was making my way back towards downtown through the Chinatown streets and caught a whiff of something magnificent, and as soon as I did; my autopilot took over and led me directly to the front doors of this establishment. I didn't bother to read the menu posted outside, I just took a look inside and saw a packed dining area and knew that was a sign that the food here was gonna be delicious(always go where lines are longest). I went inside and was instantly greeted with open arms and was told to have a seat anywhere I pleased(this was funny because there was only one table open). I didn't bother looking at the menu, I told the waitress to just bring me an order of spring rolls with peanut sauce and a medium combination Pho With Rice noodles; the same thing I order at every Vietnamese restaurant. 
  The food arrived at my table within 5 minutes of ordering and as soon as the plate hit the table, I went to work. I started with the spring rolls (soup was still too hot to eat) with peanut sauce, and man oh man were they good. They came four to an order and were stuffed full of noodles, veggies, and shrimp, and were rolled perfectly tight (I wonder what else they can roll up like a boss ;). I destroyed the spring rolls within minutes and quickly moved on to the Pho. The soup was still hot as S***, but I didn't care; I was there to grub. I'm glad I waited to eat this last, by the time I practically submerged my face into this bowl; the noodles softened up and the beef had cooked itself to medium rare, just the way I like it. The bowl was a good size for the price, and was filled with all kinds of seafood and beef; accompanied by a delicious broth and generous amount of noodles. 
  I will definitely be back here soon, I could F***  up the whole pot of this Pho, yum.
author: Joseph A.

description: I've realized that Yelp is not so reliable for certain types of eateries, so the 3.5 star rating for Golden Flower was reassuring. Chinatown restaurants need not be clean, just cheap and good-tasting. Which Golden Flower is: I decided to branch out from pho and get the #36 cold rice noodles with shrimp and pork. One of my friends and I also split an order of imperial rolls. They tasted freshly fried and very crunchy, thus yummy, though I couldn't quite distinguish what the fillings were. The noodles come with a sweet/sour/spicy sauce, same as the dipping sauce for the rolls, but I also added a bit of soy sauce for saltiness. One can easily get a satiating meal here for less than $10, so Golden Flower is a win in my book.
author: Amy G.

description:
This is a decent place to get pho. My friends and I came on a Saturday and it was packed. We got a table in the very back near the entrance to the kitchen.

I got the #1 because it was the biggest and the cheapest. I came out pretty fast. It was a decent tasting bowl of pho. No pizazz or anything. The soup did taste a bit different though. Was it a bit sour before I added anything in there?

You can reference my picture.
author: Lisa H.

description: I ordered a small Pho Tai here and it was hard not to like it. The prices are very reasonable as well - I paid $6 for it. Quick service as well, I was I and our in less than 30 minutes.
author: Jack L.

description:
Decent pho. Excellent prices. Comes out fast. Takes credit card!

Pretty clean, I don't get the impulse to clean all my utensils beforehand like I do at other places, so that's a good sign.
author: Angela L.

description:
I love this place! I finally tried it after passing by it countless times. It has a clean appearance outside that is very inviting, and they're accommodating inside as well. 

I ordered pork imperial rolls - five stars, so good. I also got a small bowl of pho with rare beef, also up to expectations. 

This was worth every dollar and I wish I'd tried this place earlier! I'll be back.
author: Denise R.

description:
So we went somewhere else first and didn't seem like we were ever going to get service and the prices were sky high so we left there and found the Golden Flower.  

It is small inside but big on service and food.  We all got something different (check pics) and now it's one of our favorites.

I had the seafood chow mein with rice noodles, 3 others had different soups and one had beef and pork fried rice.  I tried everyone's food and I liked everything.  I'm not an expert on Vietnamese food but I do know what I like.  I like spicy and good/spicy is was.

The service was friendly and fast and talk about good.  I need to learn some Vietnamese and fast so I can know what I'm ordering.  I do know it was good and everyone was more than satisfied.

And talk about affordable.  This place is a diamond in the rough.
author: MyShawn C.

description:
Wow, we found this hidden place as we looked around the corner when we were touring china town. This place probably has some of the best pho I've tasted in the bay area!! I was really pleasantly surprised.

The soup wasn't too salty and I appreciated that the noodles were not too soggy- it was perfect! I'll be going back for more!
author: Sophie P.

description: Excellent ---authentic greasy and delicious. I had the lemongrass chicken. It came spices like I asked. Also the tea was yummy! Thank you!
author: Barbara P. W.

description: Somehow the bill came up to $27 for a medium steak pho and shrimp on a stick. Couldn't read the bill so paid it and left a tip. Not sure if I'll be going again. The medium pho is $7.30 and shrimp on a stick is $8.95. $11 in tax is a bit interesting.
author: Dagan F.

description: I just love being in a china town! This is a great place also for vegeterians. I had a soup - btw if you say you want a small one it is still huge! It just have the right atmosphere. Its crowded though so you might have a trouble to find a space. The food was average but good. Deff coming back.
author: Veronika J.

description: I'm a vegan and it's very hard to find delicious Veggy pho broth anywhere. I will say, that Golden Flowers broth tops the cake! Such an AMAZING Veggy pho! Must have if you enjoy vegetarian/vegan food!
author: Cara A.

description:
Meh. I think this place was a little too overhyped for me. I got the pho combo with beef, steak, brisket, tendon, & tripe. The beef seemed a little too overcooked for me. The noodles were hard. And they only put one peice of tendon in there. 

The broth was good though & I like how this pho place stayed open later than the other ones in Chinatown.
author: Alysha K.

description:
Everything is just Golden in the world of Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco. Golden Star. Golden King. Golden Era. Golden Buddha. I'm just waiting for Golden Girls, and in would walk the Vietnamese version of Rose Nylund telling stories about St. Olaf in the far north of the Mekong Delta. But for now, Jamie W. and I settled for Golden Flower, and "settled" is the right word since the pho was just not up to snuff...fo' sho. We came here just because down the block, Hunan Homes was packed with tourists off a bus on that particular Sunday evening. Alas, Golden Flower was comparatively with the veteran waitress leaning contently against the counter. 

Of course, I went for the signature pho, the extra-large $5.15 bowl of Xe Lua, which was a combination of rare slices of steak, well-done brisket, flank, tendon, and the proverbial beef balls (see photo). With all that going for it, I was expecting more, but the broth was watery and the noodles somewhat limp. Jamie had relatively better luck with the $5.25 Ga Cari Rice Plate, which featured stir-fried chicken mixed with carrots, onions, and bell peppers in a hot curry sauce (see photo). But again, it was a pretty standard dish, suitable for the quick fix we needed at the time. Honestly, the memory of Golden Flower is fading just as I'm writing this review, and with so many Golden choices around, you'll hardly suffer for missing this particular bloom. 

FOOD - 3 stars...passable pho, just barely worth a pass
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...the standard Chinatown gig 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...served us, left us 
TOTAL - 3 stars...Golden but not golden...know what I mean?
author: Ed U.

description: Golden Flower, you aren't as good as you were a couple of years ago, but you're still quite delicious. I mean, a bowl of bun bo hue for under $10, stuffed full of noodles, hot peppers, bean sprouts, pork blood, pork knuckles, and random beef slices. Soooo good. Dirt cheap, divey, and cramped. Just my kind of place. The food comes out super quickly and is seasoned well without any salt lick, and they've got all the classic Viet drinks, including my fav - the three color. They also have the salt plum water and red bean drink. Waits aren't extensive because it's an Asian get-it-and-go place, so don't ever worry about that. A great place to eat overall.
author: Danny C.

description: Bang for your buck. Pho is always a cheap option, and this place really maximizes your dollar. I got the extra large veggie pho with beef broth, and I must say, it's pretty flippin good. I came with a party of 9, and they seated us all comfortably. The only issue that is bringing this review down by 1 star is the service. Jesus Christ. The service here genuinely makes me cringe. They got our order right, but without a joke, we asked for water 4 or 5 times. Finally, my brother got up AND GOT THE WATER HIMSELF. That really showed how bad the service was, but the lack of service is made up with the flavor of the food. Quality is a little lacking, but you get what you pay for. I still believe that the best Pho in SF is "Lovin Hut" in the Westfield mall, but this place isn't bad either. I'm from LA (where everyone is a health freak) and so this felt a little unhealthy to me. It felt very sodium and MSG filled and was clearly not made with bone marrow, but I think that's what added to the strong, distinct, good flavor of the broth here. So I would give this place a try if you're in the area.
author: Eli K.

description: Golden Flower has the best vegetarian pho I've had in the city! The staff is always super friendly and the pho never disappoints
author: Shelby G.

description:
This is my new go to spot for pho. Perfect for cold or rainy days. a Lifesaver for days when I'm struggling at work through a hangover. 
I've had better pho, but i have not found a better pho spot near here. I moved back to the area about a year ago and i really struggled to find a good pho place. 
It's a pretty small place, and they can get pretty busy at lunch. Sometimes when I go by my self they've asked me to share a table with someone, and I totally don't mind it. This place is worth it. 
I pretty much always get Pho with rare beef, usually a medium. The price is good, and I always leave satisfied. 
The staff are always very nice. They have cute decorations all over... It makes me look forward to the cooler days ahead.
author: Lacy S.

description: This is a great place for a fast lunch. The service is fast, and the pho tastes pretty good. I would come here again for lunch. I wouldn't come here with a huge group such as more than 5 people during crowded times.
author: Hina W.

description: The Pho was pretty good , kinda hard to mess that up . If you like fried tofu you absolutely have to tell them to make it like the #70 lemongrass chicken , but with tofu . It is unfrickinbelievable ! My wife and I are always on the search for the perfect tofu,  this place did it !
author: Shannon B.

description:
I miss you! Spent a weekend in SF and this was literally the greatest thing we had. Prices are great, people are wonderful and I can't wait to go back. 
The sweetest owner, made sure we were taken care of.
author: Erol G.

description: This is a great place for lunch, my wife and I ate for 20 bucks and the was great! I suggest you stop by if you like Vietnamese food! I order the Chowmein and it was reasonable for the price.
author: Brad R.

description: Very rude staff. No wonder the restaurant was almost empty while their neighbor a few doors down had a line of at least 20 people waiting. The food was ok, but nothing special and the attitude of the wait staff ruined the meal.
author: Michele D.

description:
Came here yesterday with my cousin after visiting my grandma in the hospital. Super spontaneous, my cousin had to get back to work and we needed a quick bite for lunch. This place was pretty packed, when we walked in, luckily we got a table.

To be honest, I haven't been into Chinatown for years. I practically grew up in Chinatown, but I hate looking for parking and feeling crowded, so I rarely eat in Chinatown anymore. Especially with my line of job.

Anyways, the first time I ate at this restaurant was with my mom. I also ate here a lot while I was in high school. Coming back to this restaurant brings back so much childhood memories.

I always order the #1. I use to be able to eat the extra large, I know now; however, I can't finish it. I was super shocked they allowed me to order #1 in small, that's pretty awesome. The soup was just as good as I remembered it. The noodles were good the meat was good, I just wished I remembered to order the rare steak on the side.

The decore looks the same to me, the restroom is still downstairs and not updated but, I expect it from Chinatown. I forget how much of these old places in Chinatown bring so much history.
author: Susan K.

description:
I was about to head to San Sun nearby with my parents but decided to try Golden Flower instead. 
I don't know whether or not they were just having a bad day but the pho was beyond terrible. I have eaten a number of bowls of pho and can say that the pho here was terrible. We all ordered the #1, classic beef pho with everything in it. The broth tasted like tap water, the noodles were incredibly thick, the pieces of beef were small and pathetic looking, and the hoisin sauce was watered down to a sloppy mess. 
The pho gets a 1 star but their service gets my pity +1 star. 
Definitely will stick with the other pho places around here. Don't agree with the reviews.
author: Gina T.

description:
I love pho. You should be aware I eat it about twice a week. Sometimes even more. Last week, I went here two nights in a row (getting different things of course) and then I just went last night. To be honest, I am a little embarrassed because one of the waitresses asked me if I came in earlier in the past week since she recognizes my face. I just played it off cool and neither said yes or no but she probably knows. I am going to have to start bringing more friends here so I don't seem like a total loser.

Let me start by saying that I have tried the top three things everyone likes at a vietnamese restaurant. 

Pho: Yes, its legit. Pretty damn good. Go with the medium size pho, it will fill you up like no other. You have to be pretty hungry to finish a large. BEWARE

Bun Bo Hue: BIM BO HIPPPPP. I love this stuff. Its this spicy broth with pork blood and rice noodles. If pho was the sweet girl next door, Bun Bo Hue would be the cool, hipster chick that lives across the street. You get it once in a while to get that extra flavor and kick. I prefer to get this noodle soup with the PHO noodles and not rice noodles because this noodle soup is suppose to have a lot of flavor but I think rick noodles don't soak up the flavor as well as the pho noodles; up to you. 

Vermicelli: If you really feel like a skinny gal tonight, order this. Its basically a bed of lettuce coupled with mints and sprouts with a bundle of dry vermicelli blanketed with sweet, fish Vietnamese sauce. You can order it with spring rolls on top or bbq or shrimp....(list goes on and on...) I must say, you have to ask for another thing of sauce, its simply not enough or else your noodles will be too dry. This is basically a light noodle salad( but it will fill up)!
author: Eileen W.

description: The best pho in SF. Love the people work there, sweet, friendly and happy. Feels like home.
author: Lily N.

description:
"people on yelp love us".. Sorry I can not say the same ..

The pho broth had a sour taste.. Lemon in the broth? It was not a hearty satisfying broth that I am accustomed to.  The brisket seemed really dry.. and that's usually my favorite meat. The noodles must have been cooked and put aside because once I received my pho, All the noodles were breaking apart, and some stayed clumped together.

The service was good, water was refilled without asking. The food came out fast.  Unfortunately, I can not say I will be back here again.
author: Sharon N.

description: I love this place! Good is great and service is good! I have become a frequent there now. Love the Pho and Bu Hue Spicy Soup
author: Mana K.

description:
My bf and I are definite fans of Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant!  We came here for my *birthday* lunch yesterday - he had the grilled chicken over rice vermicelli (loved the flavoring of the chicken), and I had the chicken pho sprinkled with fresh bean sprouts and basil (loved the rice vinegar-y soup base, comfort food, very comforting).  

We will definitely be back as we slurped our meals quickly, the service was nice & friendly, and the price was right!  

Our two entrees+tax+tip = $17
author: Maile N.

description: My boyfriend and I have made this our local spot. Quick service, good pho, quiet vibe. I've never gotten take out from here but eating there's always been consistently good!
author: Charlotte H.

description: Solid and cheap Vietnam kitchen. Big ass Pho for only 7 bucks! Big but not really intense of flavor. Worth the price but that's it.
author: Richy P.

description: The bean sprouts were dead. Not so pretty. The pho was pretty bland too. :( they gave us a dirty cup and we asked for a new one. We asked for new bean sprouts too but they said all were the same. We saw another table have better bean sprouts. They did offer to cook our bean sprouts but how would that work when it's already dead? Usually I would come and it would be great but this time around it was disappointing and the staff seemed to have changed again..
author: Person W.

description:
Me and the boyfriend always order the #1 and the rare beef salad.

The #1 pho is extra large. Typical pho, nothing extraordinarily (rating 2/5). 

Their rare beef salad is pretty good. Only tried the one at this place and the one on Ocean (the one on Ocean wasn't that great). rating 5/5. This time they forgot to give me bean sprouts... I was too hungry to notice..

I barely come to Chinatown and when I do, I always stop by for the rare beef salad and avocado shake at Sweet Heart.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Best Pho in SF, hands down.

Their broth and ingredients are top-notch, and you can taste it!  You can go somewhere else and pay $9 for sub-par broth, skimpy ingredients, and feel gipped -OR- you can come here, get food made with love and tradition, pay ~$6, and feel amazing.

I always order when it's been a long day, and I need some PHO-nicillin.  Thanks!
author: John P.

description:
I'm not sure if the owners are really Vietnamese...Not that it takes a Vietnamese person to cook good pho. But fact of the matter is, the Pho here lacks a bit of soul. The broth is not full and or robust like any broth should be.

With all that said, the pho comes out quick. You get your food and you are sent on your way.

Prices seem good for a downtown location.

Someone at another table ordered a chicken dish of some sort and that looked tasty.

It's not a horrible place, it's not a great place..Just ho-hum at it's best.
author: Vince N.

description:
Made the mistake of coming here for a couple of sandwiches. So I was walking back to my car and felt like grabbing a sandwich. The place I got them before were closed, so this looked like an option, especially at $3.75 each.

So I went in and got a sandwich, and was greeted in a rude manor. They told me I needed to wait 15 minutes for a sandwich? What the hell, so I decided to go to my car and put stuff away before it gets wet from the rain. They wanted my money first because they doubted anyone would wait that long especially in Chinatown, but I was stupid enough to. 

So I paid and came back in 15 minutes. The sandwiches were in the bag and they were so small that it looked like one, so after feeling the bag I realized there were two. 

When I had the time to eat, I found sandwiches bad with thin baguettes. I ordered a chicken and found half way though, they used dark meats. I realized this after biting into what I thought was a bone, later to realize it was a leg joint.
author: M C.

description:
Pho Ga - 5/5
Combination vegetarian riceb- 3.5/5
Will eat here again - 5/5 definitely.

loved this place, really nice and homely place, the green tea served with the lunch was amazing and the best I have ever had
author: Rachit A.

description:
Stopped by this week and ordered two items:

Noodle Soup #16 (Hu Tieu Thap Cam) or the seafood rice noodle soup:

I did not enjoy this bowl of eats. 
First, the soup was very very salty. 
It didn't taste home-made at all.
The rice noodles clumped together in this starchy-mass of clumpiness. 

The bowl had 4 shrimps, 6 small calamari pieces, 3 fish balls, and 1 piece of imitation-crab meat (yes.....I counted).

On the other hand, I ordered a round of fried Imperial rolls:
These rolls were enjoyable.
They had moist ground pork inside.

Maybe an off-day for them?
It was quite busy when I ate there.
author: Derek N.

description:
I had a simple rare steak pho (Tai).... and my steak was hard and tough to chew on... gross...

I was starting my hangover, so the soup was AMAZING to me at that point.

I'm only giving them an extra star because they were 10 minutes from closing, yet they still sat us and took great care of us.  Kudos to them for that.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
While earning $20.00 per day to serve as a juror, my wife can do much better than spending her small earning and buy instant ramen noodles. We all know that.

I also love my new work-vehicle with all the necessary accessories that Law enforcement agencies use and drive. In my case and other than my job, I also drive the car to look for my wife in Chinatown and took her to a Vietnamese Restaurant for a deserving dinner.  

I had the Lemongrass Chicken over Rice (#49). For $6.95, I get chicken pieces grilled with Vietnamese spices, egg roll, rice and vegetables. I've also added a side of shredded Pork for an additional $1.50. The poultry piece was spiced well and tender, but the eggroll tasted awkard with a weird taste. I couldn't think what the taste was like, but it wasn't too pleasing. 

Wife took a $7.95 bowl of Grilled Pork with Cold Vermicelli Noodles, Egg Roll, Bean Spruts and vegetables (#40). I don't know the name of the bowl, but I think many of you know which popular bowl dish I'm talking about. According to her, the meat was a bit too burnt and dry. And the bean sprouts didn't look too fresh either. With many good produce markets in Chinatown, we wondered what was the reason of poor quality foods served here. 

I shoud've took her elsewhere but here. Or, I should've let her buy instant Ramen Noodles. 

But she is not a criminal and she deserves much better food. 

My decision in coming here; "MY BAD!"
author: Matt G.

description:
Tiny cute place. We really loved it! We waited longer than we would've liked since we were super hungry, but that's okay, it was busy/packed because it was Xmas ;P 
We were served hot sugarless tea - my husband said it was flavorless but I loved it. We got vegetarian spring rolls with peanut sauce and vegetarian pho - both were fresh and yummy, and the soup was HUGE. We really only needed 1 appetizer and 1 soup for both of us to share, and like I said - we were hungry!
Very refreshing, healthy and tasty!
author: Maya C.

description:
Not bad. 

We went here mostly because my mom really wanted soup (it was a chilly day.) We all ended up sharing a large pho and some spring rolls, mostly because I wasn't really hungry (after gorging myself with dim sum.)

I really didn't eat much of the pho, but what I had wasn't bad at all. Nice, beefy, and flavorful. Had a lot of nice pieces of beef. The bowl was HUGE, and for $7-something, it was a great deal. The spring rolls were a nice snack/appetizer. It was definitely homemade and tasty.

Overall, for the amount of food you get and the cheap prices, it's not a bad place to get your pho/Vietnamese food fix.
author: Katherine M.

description:
BIG JUICY BALLS.

Beef balls that is, if you order the #6 pho bowl. They were very generous with their pho toppings. Most joints will give you pathetic beef ball halves but Golden Flower puts six WHOLE MONSTROUS balls in their beef pho. Soup is very savory. The only thing that beats a hot meal on a cold day is pho noodle soup from Golden Flower.

Golden Flower is the real deal. It's been here for at least 20 years. Over the past decades, I've gradually seen more Vietnamese restaurants sprouting but place holds the crown to best Vietnamese restaurant not only in the Chinatown neighborhood, but in SF.   

Very cheap indeed -- our bill tallied around $20 for three people. Left with our wallet barely lighter much our bellies much fuller. YAY!
author: Annie L.

description: Every time I come to SF I will make a mandatory stop here (and sometimes even twice). Best spring rolls, egg rolls, Pho and especially Stir Fry I have ever had.
author: Jonah M.

description: My go-to for pho in my neighborhood. Cheap, filling, and excellent flavor to the broth. Portions are large, even if you order the small size. Service is very fast and everyone is so friendly here, which is the main reason I keep returning. The restaurant is small and gets very crowded at lunch time, so try to arrive early if you have a big group. I haven't ordered anything except pho and spring rolls here (I'm in a rut!), but the rice and noodle dishes look delicious too.
author: Alison S.

description:
This is my first time back here since they have changed owners

I used to come here when I was in middle school, the previous owner was really nice and very warming....but this review isn't about that

The new store...its a lil weird to me, they have all these decorations and stuff to make it look...more viet? iono...its not homey....catered to tourist i suppose

I ordered a Pho with the beef balls and steak....the service was nice but my taste in pho..yea...the broth was good, but the meat...was bland...like it was....water and meat..and the noodle....was alright, a little softer than i would like....

i would only come back...if all the phos place in Chinatown was closed and im craving pho (which was what happen anyways =P)
author: Laurie W.

description: We stumbled across this restaurant during a weekend getaway.  It's a hole in a wall with everyday average Vietnamese fare.  Their tofu spring rolls were OK but their seafood pho was pretty good.  They do have a large number of vegetarian choices listed, but the item I picked, which was tofu with basil fell flat.  It was not very flavorful and the fried tofu did not tasted fresh.  I think they need to work on putting more love into their foods and cook with more enthusiasm - then I will come back for more!
author: Susie D.

description:
Like a lot of authentic Asian places, you have to really understand that if their wait staff doesn't speak English well, you need to lower your expectations of service like in most English speaking restaurants. They are attentive but not invasive.

The food is awesome and exploring the menu is half the fun. Of course they have Pho, but the rest of the menu is really a treat. The spring rolls were crisp and freshly made.
author: John L.

description:
This place is so low key and from the outside it looks boring.

Well, it is boring, that is to say the decor.

Food quality is up there though.

I was craving something different, and my friend recommended the #36.
This is a plate of BBQ'd beef and shrimps, with shredded carrots, basil, fresh bean sprouts over a bed of thin rice noodles. The beef tasted freshly grilled and shrimps tasted freshly grilled too. A solid meal.

If you don't eat peanuts, be sure to tell them 'No Peanuts'. $7.25 is a fair price for good quality.

The Cafe Sua Da was very good too.

In about 10 minutes, we had our food and my food looked deelish. As it was really deelish, I will be coming back again. I would recommend this place as A-Ok for food quality. But read on...

Decor: homey, low rent and the heater was off ! Brrrr...everyone was wearing their jackets; but the food is good.
 
Customer service: first rate and personable.
author: Bert K.

description: This is a great casual ( read sweatpants and t-shirt) pho place. As vegetarians we tried a couple of other pho places with veggie options but once we found this we stopped looking. Flavorful veggie broth and I like that they always confirm that we want veggie broth as opposed to the beef. And once we  come here a couple times they remembered what we got! Left off one star cause parking is impossible ... Don't even... And it's a little dingy but we're regulars!
author: Nikhil A.

description:
Stopped by this relatively spacious place (for chinatown) for some pho and bun bo hue. The pho was pretty good and lived up to any other pho I've had. 

However, the Bun bo hue was odd, and seemed to be in pho broth or something, and not the standard type I've been used to, and was merely "A-OK" in yelp terminology.
author: Oliver Z.

description: I'm not sure how this restaurant has received 5 stars. The summer salad roll was okay. I went with the rare beef pho. Broth wasn't there. Noodles had no flavor. No thank you.
author: Mayra M.

description:
