Been here 2x.  The owner, Kim, is a sweetheart.  She even gave me tea while I wait for my take-out dinner.  I ordered Bo Tai Chanh (raw beef salad) each time.  It was good, but the quality isnt consistent.  

I also ordered their fried noodles with seafood.  Kim recommended it highly.  I went home, and was disgusted.  I am not a picky eater.  I love a good bowl of bun bo hue any day.  But that pan fried noodle, recommended by the owner was just inedible.

Sorry Kim, I dont think I will be coming back.
author: Joyce P.

description:
This place hits home because my best friend and I had our weekly Sunday brunch here after graduating high school and before departing our separate ways to college. Nice hot bowl of pho + deep talks about life = awesome :D 

I'm not Vietnamese so I can't comment on whether or not the soup and preparation of the beef and noodles are legit. But I hear (and believe) it is. My first few visits here, I always got a #9 small (with well done flank?) because I'm not a huge fan of tripe or the uncooked beef slices. After awhile, I began to try their rice dishes which are really delicious! The boneless lemongrass chicken rice plate is served with sour & spicy fish sauce which I like to pour all over the chicken AND rice. Although the chicken was sometimes hard/difficult to chew, I still come back and order it again. 

Try to avoid rush hour (lunch time around 12-1pm) because during these times, I felt a little rushed to finish what I was eating quickly and leave for new customers to be seated. The owner (the woman behind the counter?) is really sweet, and I can tell she does her best to cater to tourists and new customers by introducing and explaining dishes. I'm a regular here so I don't get that special treatment. 

Compared to other pho places in SF (on Irving and down the alley to Golden King?), I think you get a lot more noodles here.
author: Winnie H.

description: The spring rolls are a MUST - very fresh and delicious. This is my favorite place to get pho in the city.
author: Becca R.

description: Wow. Portions are really large. Family run Vietnamese which is charming. Vietnamese coffee is nice and refreshing on a hot day. The place is full of Vietnamese and westerners. A good sign IMO. Not as authentic as a dirty local restaurant in Hanoi but that's being picky. We left satisfied.
author: Will S.

description: It's yum yum!! Love the flavorful food!! Service is great!! It's so close to my work!!
author: Ericka C.

description:
When I think of Chinatown, four things come to mind: dim sum, Little Paris Vietnamese sandwiches, Chinese food, and smelly fish markets. When it comes to food, you and I probably wouldn't think of anything else to eat besides Chinese food in Chinatown, right? Ah, but you see, that is where I am wrong.
 
This little gem has a lot to offer to me, to you, and anyone else that doesn't want to eat Chinese food in Chinatown. I was with a friend and I really wanted some noodles, particularly cold vermicelli noodles with meat, chopped up veggies, and the infamous sweet and tangy sauce poured all over it. I remembered looking up on Yelp for a place to eat in Chinatown and I bookmarked this place to give it a try. It was kind of difficult to find this restaurant among a midst of hundreds of restaurants clumped together on busy Chinatown streets, but I couldn't have been happier when I recognized the bright blue banner that read "Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant".

I ordered what I was craving which was the vermicelli noodles with beef and imperial rolls, while my friend ordered the #1 large bowl of pho. His usual, as always. As we waited for our food to come out, I was fixated on the number of people that came in and out of the restaurant. This place was poppin'. I could tell this place was a popular joint because as one table cleared out, another group quickly came in to fill up the table. It was rather impressive. Before we know it, our food arrived on our table; it didn't take more than ten minutes for the food to come out.

Needless to say, the food was spot on and delicious. Golden Flower gets a golden star in my book. Or well, yelp account. Heh.
author: Annie S.

description:
A pretty small place with pretty good food! 
Go and try their curry! It came out fast, fresh and fills you up for a very low price. What else can you wish?!
author: Daniel J.

description: Really yummy food and service was very kind and attentive. The spring rolls were delish!!!
author: Sheelah P.

description: Just had the Bun with grilled pork and imperial rolls.  Very fresh and good quality.  Rolls not as good as Tu Lan, but pork had less fat and grease, plus the ambiance and neighborhood make up for a lot that Tu Lan is lacking.
author: Josh K.

description: Really good Pho. Came across this place while exploring Chinatown. The portions are really good for the price and the food is really good. The beef broth they put in their Pho is some of the best I've ever tasted. I would recommend if you are near this place and are craving something warm on a cold Bay night, go to the Golden Flower.
author: Russ K.

description:
Found this place by accident, really tasty pho, and practically empty. Surprising, since there were lines out the door for other places just around corners. 

Owner was very nice, they were very attentive and helpful. I'd recommend this place to a friend.
author: Jesse J.

description:
This is a small family run Vietnamese restaurant on a side street in Friscos china town
The food tasted very fresh and was cooked to order I had the ginger chicken it was great and very resonalbly priced
author: David W.

description:
DON'T LAUGH I USE A FORK, CHOPSTICKS, AND SOUP SPOON!
(3.5 Stars)

I don't smell like armpit! That's one thing you have to judge about a Pho places, ventilation. And this palce you will definately not see alot of "FiDi business people" as the other Pho restaurants in Chinatown. 

- Food, good/decent
- Prices, affordable
- Service, good/quick 
- Ambiance, small but cleaner then many vietnamese restaurants

We found a new Pho spot in Chinatown with decent prices. Our typical place which is down the block from here decided to hike their pho prices by 40%, therefore it was time for us to find a new spot. Thanks Yelp! Decided to come here after reading reviews and "asian" people givign it petty decent ratings. But of course, I've had better pho and I've had much worst; however this is not just okay this is on the pretty good side of the border.

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS
my friends at work and i decided to get some Pho for lunch. Since they don't have yelp accounts...

Mike M. "(Pho Tai) it's cheaper! this is pretty good but I like Golden Star better. next time I come here, i'm getting BUN BO HUE. Good job Jane in finding this place."

Sheryl C. "(Pho Ga) it's cheaper here! i stil like Golden Star's broth better but overall this place is good... BECAUSE I LIKE THIS shredded CHICKEN =)"

PHO GA (small $5.75) - It's first instinct to judge a pho place by their simple dishes first before considering to be experimental. I sipped the broth - yummy. Noticed in their broth they added cabbage! The chicken was real chicken because you know some places you just don't know if it's chicken or some other kind of animal; just saying! And the noodles were yummy, not too mooshy and not undercooked. Overall, it was pretty good pho for $5.75 in chinatown. 

Will I be back? Yes we will!

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: This place is probably the best quality pho in the city.  And reasonably priced too.  Highly recommend.
author: Maria R.

description:
They added a hand written sign on the door that they are now serving Bun Bo Hue...that sign has since changed to a real printed sign.  

They were packed when we got there with the door open - it's a warm night so the opened door definitely help.  Luckily, we got the table next to the door.  The lady was in such a rush to take our order, she walked away before  was done.

What we had:

Rare beef salad - slices of thinly sliced beef with a lot of onion, basil and peanuts served with a bowl of fish sauce.  Generous portion and very good.

Bun bo hue - I asked for extra spicy and it was barely spicy.  They also don't serve it with the right condiments like banana flower.  I asked for extra spice on the side a few times with no luck.  Out of frustration, I walked up to the counter and asked if they have some kind of chili oil or anything that can help spice up my soup noodle.  Five minute after, a half bowl of chili oil was brought to our table.  Dumping the entire content finally got the soup noodle looking like it should.  It comes with slices of pork loaf, couple pieces of pork feet, a piece of pork blood and slices of beef shank.

grilled chicken and imperial rolls bun - instead of the rice noodle, it was served with the bigger round noodle.  

iced coffee on ice - strong and tasty.
author: Gloria H.

description:
A coworker brought me here for lunch and the food was delicious. i had the pork imperial rolls and rice and it was super good.

She ordered the beef stew and it was super crazy big and delicious as well.

+ extra imperial rolls order

total bill 18

will come again and would recommend!
author: Fran M.

description:
Best vietnamese sandwich ever! I got the BBQ pork viet sandwich and it was BOMB AF. I love how the bread is super crunchy and the meat is roasted to PERFECTION (not too burnt or overcooked as some places make it). Theres also alot of carrots that make it extra yummy and some jalepenos to make it just spicy enough but not too spicy. The portion was also pretty good and filled me up :)

However, wait is 15-20 min for a sandwich because they make it fresh! I think its totally worth it though because of how delicious it is.

Also, the owner was super nice. Even though I came in during a lunch rush she was really attentive even though my friend and I were only ordering take out and made sure our takeout was to par before we left. She also told me to call in next time I want a sandwich to avoid waiting.
author: Cindy L.

description: Delicious!! Been here all weekend and this was definitely the best meal I've had in all of San Francisco. The owner is a very sweet lady and makes sure you are happy.
author: Adriana G.

description:
I really love this place for their Bon Bo Hue! From all of the Bon Bo Hues I have tasted nothing comes close to this one!

In addition, the staff are super nice and friendly! And that is really rare in San Francisco's Chinatown. This place fast, affordable and they give you a good portion of food as well.
author: Yummy T.

description: Pho on a budget.
author: Scott M.

description:
This place is inexpensive.

We walked out paying 20 bucks for 2 small bowls of pho and 4 spring rolls.  Not bad, right?

As far as the taste goes, I think it's average, not great but not bad.
author: Oriana C.

description: Had the pho chin.  Amazingly, astoundingly cheap prices, good broth, and an abundance of steak.  The large is so large why settle for a small? I need to go back for the bun bo hue! Gets pretty busy at lunch, so expect to wait a bit and get friendly with your fellow guests.
author: Cody P.

description: Reminds me of good old times with mom when she use to take me to chinatown. BUT the food isn't all the great, average pho. Staff was attentive though.
author: Tiff W.

description:
If I were to write this review 10 years ago, I would be giving this place 0 stars (is that possible?). The last time I was here, meaning that one time over 10 years ago, I had such a horrible experience that I swear I would never come back.

I don't quite remember exactly what it was, but I was there with my family for dinner. They did something rude to our table, my parents complained about it and ended up getting yelled at by the staff. I have never been to a restaurant where we get yelled at for something rude they did. It was unbelievable.

However, time passed and my friends invited me to have lunch. She chose this place because she loves the raw beef there. I thought it was time to try this place again and see if there were improvements. It was really packed there, given that it was lunch time. They were lacking the speed of service. I asked for a glass of ice water and I didn't get it until it was asked for the second time.

They accidentally spilled something on my place mat and took the liberty to switch out for a new one for me. Over all, I guess the service is better, maybe it was run by new owners and staff?

Food wise, it was okay, not the best. I've had better soup base.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Decent Vietnamese food. The spring rolls are huge, but filled with mostly noodles to bulk up their size. Very plain so lots of sauce is needed.

The rice place was decent. My pork chop was well seasoned. The addition of the egg on top is good, but next time I'll tell them over easy. I didn't specify and it was sunny side up and very raw tasting.
author: John H.

description:
Somehow I convinced my mom that Pho and Vietnamese was the same as Chinese food.  See, I had to try the Pho in SF and we were in Chinatown, so when in Rome.  My entourage doesn't really get the whole Phobsession, but luckily I could persuade them to eat here instead of the neighboring Chinese joint.  I ordered a small bowl with the beef on the side.  My mom and sis got beef and chicken dishes.  The Pho was pretty tasty.  All the ingredients were fresh tasting and the broth was just right.  The small was more than enough for me.  They gave ample amount of meat as well as all the trimmings.  My sis really liked her chicken curry dish and my mom mentioned she had had better beef and broccoli. 

The service was really friendly.  Our waitress checked on us a lot and also chatted with us.  She overheard our conversation and decided to join in.  Super friendly.

It was reported back to me that the bathrooms here are super scary.
author: Jennifer B.

description: One of our favourite Vietnamese restaurants to go for a bowl of phò. Huge bowls,  nicely seasoned and not to salty. Friendly staff.
author: Karlijn V.

description:
Although, I can always have Vietnamese food at homes at times, when my friends want to get Vietnamese then I order shrimp spring rolls my all time favorite. I'm very simple, but some places have very disgusting tasty shrimp. This place at least it taste semi-fresh. 

Service is great!!! (:  I would come back here again if I was in the neighborhood and craving spring rolls.
author: Lisa T.

description: Traditional Vietnamese, very friendly staff. I had a bowl of Pho with 4 or 5 different meats and the grilled beef appetizer with fish sauce. Both were delicious. The pre meal bean sprouts with sweet/spicy sauce was refreshing. My wife had the ginger chicken and rice noodles. Needless to say, there was nothing left on the plates.
author: Jimmy L.

description: This is the original spot that first introduced me to my love affair with Vietnamese food. I usually ordered the rare beef with beef balls. the bowls were small but enough for me at the time. It was also cheap at $5. I also lived eating their seafood noodle soup. The noodles were always perfectly cooked, clear clean flavorful broth, with fresh ingredients. it's great to know you can find good eats in Chinatown and not compromise quality in ingredients. the beef carpaccio was also delicious. park in the garages to avoid hassle!
author: Connie C.

description:
This has been my first place to ever have pho and has been my go to spot for good pho in Chinatown and it has gone downhill these past couple of years.
 Last time I came here, there was was a roach in my pho; broth was watered down and bland. I told the waiter and the lady in the front apologized and got me a new one right away.  It was nice of her to do so but by that time I had already lost my appetite.
author: J. G.

description:
Was on the search for the best pho in the bay area... Good pho here.. In second place for pho.
By the way my number one choice is.... Pho 2000 awsome pho
author: Lana H.

description: I should've come here hungry. The pho is yummy, and I think I could've gone without adding the siracha, but that's an automatic for me now. Yes it was worth the trek from Fisherman's Wharf to here.
author: Ami K.

description:
Not too impressed by my beef dish here: It tasted like oil and had the texture of rubber.  I'm understating it too; this was the worst thing I've probably ever eaten in a restaurant.

The pork dish that my friend had was quite good.  But that beef scared me away forever.
author: D B.

description:
This joint is one of the few places that I frequent when going to lunch in Chinatown.  The dishes I order most often are #1, big beef pho, or #40 the vermicelli noodles with grilled pork and egg rolls, but always followed by iced Vietnamese Coffee. 

Granted, this is not THE best place for pho, but it works for me when I am in the mood for some pho during lunchtime in the FiDi on a weekday.  Considering the quality of food, and the portion I get for the price I pay, I do not have much to complain about. 

However, I will say that the place can get extremely packed during the 12-2pm bracket given the small space of the restaurant. Ventilation may not be optimal when the place is packed and every single person orders hot steamy pho, causing a rise to indoor temperature.  

Do not take things personal when the waitstaff decides to stick (2) parties of one at the same table.  This is standard procedure for them (as with many other noodle joints) especially when seating is of the essence.
author: Michael C.

description:
I keep coming back and keep loving the food here.  Yesterday was grilled pork, 2 cha gio and served with rice.  Not a thing wrong with it.  The pork was deliciously seasoned.  Contrary to the experience of other diners/reviewers, this was lean and not at all fatty.  

I need to try the pho one of these days.  Golden Flower is my go-to vietnamese spot for lunch.  If only they made vietnamese sandwiches, this place would be perfect!
author: Donna H.

description: This is the best pho place in the neighborhood! They serve authentic Vietnamese food and the service is amazing. They never fail to serve a perfect meal!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I have been at this Vietnamese restaurant a total of two times. I always order numero 1 since I love pho. I am not 100% satisfied with the service but its fine as long as the foods good.  

***FRIENDSNOTE*** 
They complain that I sit there for a hour to eat one bowl. THE FOODS GOOD, BUT NOT THAT GOOD FOR ME TO  BREATHE IT IN.
author: Cleo C.

description:
It was my first time there and didn't know how the food was.  So to play it safe, I ordered the special Pho (#2).  Coworkers ordered some rice dish and noodle dish. 

Mine was pretty good, but I wished they gave more veggies. As for my coworkers, they said their dish were good too and they wanted to come back. I will come back for the Bun Bo Hue.

The price of my large bowl of pho was $7.55.  Service was not bad. The ceiling was kind of low, so it felt a bit cramped. All in all, the atmosphere was pretty welcoming.
author: Troy V.

description:
OVERALL:3.6   FOOD:4   SERVICE:3.5   AMBIANCE:3   VALUE:4
English is optional, low-quality, and sometimes non-existent, but the food makes everything better!  Generous portions, fresh ingredients, quality meats, HOT!, fragrant flavors, customizable!

Loved the 5-Spice Chicken Pho (added bok-choy & broccoli for $1):
Light, ungreasy broth+al dente noodles+juicy roast chicken thigh.

Pretty extensive menu includes tons of non-pho options that I'll be back to try!
author: Amy K.

description: my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in ct. There are a lot of restaurants in Chinatown. They also have a lot of Vietnamese restaurants but I find that Golden Flower is most authentic. Whenever I'm in the area and I'm not getting dim sum, its Golden Flower! I tried a lot of dishes here and they have never failed me. Cold days i prefer Pho Tai (steak flanks) and when its hot, I usually get their Bun dishes, Usually the one with imperial rolls and Thit Nuong (i think it's pork?) and Viet Coffee :) yumm
author: Kristina L.

description: Service was good, but the food not so.  I ordered chicken pho and found a huge gnat it with wings, antennas and everythjng.  The pho itself was ok. Kinda looked watered down. The bowls were big, but didn't have enough noodles or meat. The chicken itself was real tough as if it's been sitting out. My fiancé ordered bbq chicken rice plate & he mentioned that it was sour and not good.  He barely ate 4 bites and couldn't eat anymore.  My daughter had spring rolls which were ok. Don't think I'm coming back here again.
author: dina d.

description: Awful. For a vegetarian especially. I am sure what I ordered-- veggie curry-- was not actually veg. I wanted to walk out when I saw the disgusting bathroom in the basement but I wanted to "be nice" so I tried. I was super hungry but ate 3 bites of my food (which was not what I ordered. Not anything that resembles any curry I've ever seen and it had tofu and the menu item did not and I specified no tofu! ) but sometimes restaurants where the staff don't speak English think they are doing me a favor giving me free tofu I didn't order. So I picked out a piece of broccoli and tried wiping the gooey brown sauce off on the rice. Oh god. Just don't. Don't do it.
author: Dawn S.

description: This is a very inexpensive place. They have the pictures of the food so that you don't have to think about what you want. It's right in the middle of Chinatown you have to really look for it because there are a ton of competitors and you might miss it. The imperial roll is just ok.
author: Jorge P. G.

description:
This place was so good. The beef noodle soup was the best. We ordered the fried rolls, one beef noodle soup, one beef pho and some chow mein. Everything was very good...probably the best noodle soup I've had in the city. 

I think the beef noodle soup is much much tastier than the Pho.

And it's cheap and fast. Love it!
author: Zarpana K.

description:
Tendon. Tripe. Brisket. It's not a menu option but they do me right by it every time I ask. Huge portions. Better than any pho I've had in Little Saigon in Westminster - yea, that's what I said!

Lemon beef carpaccio. Awwwwsome.

God I love this place. It's worth every congested honk across the city.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Imperial rolls and large #5 (beef pho).  The pho is going to come out VERY hot.  The Imperial rolls will give you something to eat while the pho cools down.  Can't go wrong at this place.

**Lost my Duke status to some jerk named Will.  Pretty sure that guy is using fake check in's.
author: Travis W.

description: Quick lunch, massive portions, Beef Pho & Vietnamese springs rolls all for $12...you can't go wrong.
author: Gar Wing L.

description:
GPS-ed my way here after a night out with some friends. I got the smaller pho combo with steak, brisket, tendon and tripe. The portion was pretty good, but my two male friends who (of course) ordered the large noticed that there wasn't too much additional food in their bowls. As another reviewer mentioned on here, a large pho means ridiculously large bowls but not larger portions.

I liked the pho but I wasn't blown away. The meat was just all right, not too flavorful. The steak and tripe were kind of tough. The broth was well-seasoned and didn't taste like there was a lot of MSG (I couldn't tell if they used real beef stock or not). I was really impressed by the noodles - I'm so tired of mushy or grainy noodles, and thankfully these were bouncy/elastic. 

The restaurant is small but has lots of tables and seats. Relatively clean (for Chinatown) and food came quickly. Oh, and it's really cheap! Huge plus. Will probably come again since it's so close to where my friends live.
author: Katie M.

description:
Found this place on a whim.  My friend and I were trying to get into The Great Eastern dim sum down the street, but the front desk guy was dicking us around so we left frustrated.  We had both spotted the pho place on our way into Chinatown so we both agreed let's get some freaking food into us.  This was especially perfect for Sunday afternoon hangover relief.

I hung my head into my #7 large (rare beef and meatball) and dug in.  I always try the broth first to see if I need to add anything and was impressed.  No need to add anything.  But of course I'm in San Francisco Chinatown, so what should I expect?  The best meaty broth I've ever had, and I love me some pho.

The place became crowded and a bit loud after we got into this tiny space, but we didn't mind.  We had meaty soup in front of us.

Great find!
author: Meg B.

description:
We went here for lunch today and ordered two large chicken noodle soups. However, while eating my husband noticed insect/fly inside the soup, so we let our server know. And this is what we got back - a wide wide smile from her! Forget about saying sorry, there's not even an expression of sorry on her face, infact she was giggling with her colleague on the billing counter! 
We asked her to take off both the soups from the bill, and they agreed only after we told them a few times. 
Hygiene is the most important thing when you go out to eat, everything else is secondary! ZERO STARS Golden Flower!
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description:
Coworkers and I hit up this spot when we're craving for some pho.  

I usually order the rare steak and meatballs pho. (6 for Small, 7ish for Large)  The rare steak does come out still rare when served, which is always a good sign.  The meatballs is decent, but nothing to rave about.  The broth is pretty good.  Not too salty.  

Springs rolls (6ish) are pretty good, peanut sauce is above average.  

Imperial rolls (6ish) are pretty fried...not sure when the last time they changed their oils.  They do serve their rolls with a side of noodles that you can eat it with, but wish they would give you more than one lettuce leaf so you can wrap it.  

You can get out of this joint (as most pho joints) for under $10.  Which is winning for SF.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Good spot to duck into in the midst of all the hustle and bustle of Chinatown, especially in the evening after the new year parade. Got seats quick, got an order taken quick, got the food pretty quick, and got the check quick. 

Well, I got seafood soup. Wish I hadn't. The broth and noodles were really good, warm soup hit the spot since I was freezing, which almost makes me want to give them more stars. But, honestly, the seafood was gross, I've had better. Also, didn't like the fact that I was given a big bowl when I requested a small. Many others looked satisfied with their food though...my experience was meh.
author: Lily K.

description:
Food = good. Decent portions (we had leftovers). Good flavors.  I tried their lemon grass chicken over vermicelli...yum.  My sister had their beef pho...yummy broth, a lot clearer than I'm used to, but good.   (Nothing happened to us, but we witnessed an unhappy client, with her soup...fly in it.  *shrugs*)  

Decor = simple with bright fluorescents.  Nothing fancy but a decent quick lunch/dinner place.  

Prices = cheap, under $10/pp (or under $7 if you know where to look.)

Parking = I have no idea.  We walked here after work in FiDi.  So yeah...g'luck.

Oh they lose a star, because they started mopping (with bleach) while there were still diners (being us) trying to eat their meals!!
author: Fannie S.

description: My husband and I had upset stomach and run to the bathroom several times after visiting this dirty restaurant. I dunno where to complain about their food safety and bad service.
author: Julie S.

description:
Golden Flowerr babyy!!! Theres a lot of vietnamese restaurants around my area, since living in the TL...and also being from a family from vietnam...I SERIOUSLYY would only head over to chinatown to get some PHO from this place, because its just seriously BOMB/DELICIOUS!!! MUST TRY!! I always get the #1 with EXTRA onions...and ladies/gentlemen, they sure remember me...haha! Also with the sweet welcome from the Owner, sigh always brighten up your dayy...

I recommend their imperial rolls as well...delicious...
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I appreciate "real" pho, but I don't crave it, ever.  

Nothing amazing, but nothing bad.  Just your standard pho shop with msg stock on the salty side.  The flavor is OK, but noticeably lacking; it's made up for by being salty.  It's run by Chinese people, so you should know what to expect.  If you're seeking some legit pho, hit up San Jose or La Petite Camille here in Millbrae.
author: Christopher L.

description: We ate here last week and it was awesome. You have to dig deep into Chinatown to get here and it's worth it. I got #36 (can't remember the name) but it was basically a huge bowl of awesome noodles and healthy stuff topped with shrimp and pork. My word - so good. Definitely give this place a try!
author: Evie K.

description: Wonderful!! The plates were large enough to share, but too delicious and I didn't want to share! They had a large enough vegetarian menu with wonderful options. I wish we lived closer!
author: Stacy K.

description: First time in china town! And this place was amazing- we had pho  that's soooo good. I believe the owner was serving us whom was super friendly and just gave us a homie / cozy feeling!!! Best pho ever!
author: Veronica A.

description:
food: Bo Tai Chanh Lemon Rare Beef!!! its oddly in the salad section of the menu. if you can stomach the idea of eating slices of raw beef, this is the dish to go for. it comes in slices topped with cilantro, peanuts, and some nuoc mam sauce. the meat is tender to the bite. it has a sweet and a hint of sourness to the crunch and the aromatics of the herbs used. not many places have this and if they do they cant replicate this simple dish. ***5/5

service: it can get crowded, but the place is so small enough that its easy to get somebodys attention. ***4/5

ambiance: not exactly the best. but the food makes up for it. ***3/5

price: the cost for the dish have gone up over the years, but still worth it. i used to live in sf but moved to seattle and i will try my best to come here just to eat this dish. ***4/5
author: Andy Z.

description: Very modest but INCREDIBLE vietnamese food made traditionally by an immigrant couple with nothing but  great inherited home made recipes.  Every plate we ordered was amazingly full of flavor... Thank you.
author: Roberto S.

description:
PHO IS YUMMY.. babe got the small pho which seem like a LARGE SIZE. The broth is so full of flavor, the noodles are nicely cooked. Meat is not overcooked or undercooked. 

Complimentary tea.. 

Eggrolls are the BOMB

--- If your ever in chinatown - dont eat anywhere else.. we tried 2 places before we found this spot and its cheap!

Did I mention they won best of the bay and TIM LINCECUM wrote an article about this place? 

Definetly gotta go back here next time we hit up Chinatown
author: Cheryllyn L.

description: One of the most authentic, most down-home, and most perfect Viet restaurants I've ever been to, anywhere. The pho is of course a leading attraction but my favorite is easily the clay-pot catfish. The prices are very cheap, too, and their variety and quality can't be beat. It can get very crowded at lunch, so try to come later or earlier to beat the crowd. I've also always been very impressed with how fresh everything they use in their cooking appears to be, and how tasty, which I suppose goes to prove that con gà tt mã v lông, rng en v thuc, ru nng v men.
author: Mike W.

description:
I don't understand why so many tourists as well as San Francisco locals like to come to this restaurant. There are so many other Pho restaurants in the city...and just around the block even. The noodles have a bad aftertaste that makes you consider how long it's been out. The meats that are put into the noodles also have that "stale" aftertaste. Last but not least, the broth is terrible. I always consider the broth to be the one ingredient that puts the entire bowl together, but the broth here is sour. Basically, after taking your first bite, you wonder how long the entire dish have been pre-prepared for its customers.

Other than the pho quality, the service was good. The waiters/waitresses are really friendly and the atmosphere of the restaurant is nice too.
author: Carrie H.

description: Came here for lunch the five spice chicken was delicious it was meaty and wasnt too dry and it still retains all the flavor. Haven't tried their noodle soup but majority of the people ordering were noodle soup or either a rice plate. Not bad even though there's other vietnamese restaurants around the area too
author: Linh D.

description: Very disappointed! If you look for a good Vietnamese restaurant, don't go to this one! I don't know why they have those number of customers, I have been to many Vietnamese restaurant in the SF, this is the one I really want to give this negative feedback here, because they don't listen to the customer's order patiently, I called them to order a spicy beef pho, the person picked up the phone did not let me finish my talking then ended my call, then when I walked to pick up my order, they said non of them placed my order, and asked me to wait 10 mins to Wait, they were too busy to say anything, even I asked them make sure they were making the noodle for me, I asked" r you making it for me?then the boss? Or just a cashier said very inpatient"I don't make it for you, the people inside the kitchen make for u, just wait! " she is rude!!!!! It was my lunch hour, I have no other choice then I waited at the end.  and their food is just so so, the noodle is just ok, and the soup is so so, and the meats is just too small, thin, and Smash, and cost $9.50. Without any meat I regular have, this is very suck. Won't go there anymore, and not recommend for you first come to SF, go other place!
author: Ciel S.

description: I had a vegetarian plate that consistef of sauteed vegetables in curry sauce, fried rice and some tea. The curry sauce was excellent and I normally don't like it. I would come again. This was my first time here. Oh and the bathroom was very clean.
author: Victor J.

description:
So far so good... A little duct tape on the menu didn't detour us from eating in this little gem of a place. The staff were so friendly. Filled with big, warm smiles and a "sit anywhere you'd like!" We ordered the Vegetarian Pho. It came with an abundance of vegetables (bok choy, broccoli, mushrooms and thinly sliced carrots) and of course the topping items. The basil, sprouts, jalapeño peppers and lime were perfectly fresh.
This clean, aromatic dish left was exactly what we were looking for. Truly satisfying! The best part... Two of us ate for $13.60! with tea!
 A new favorite place is beeing added to the list!
author: Miss M.

description: The food is just decent, but I go back over and over because of the friendly ladies who work here.  It's a good spot if you want to eat lunch out but need to be quick about it.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Damn good Pho. 
Simple, tasty and cheap!!! Portions are big, the small is perfect for me and the spring rolls are yummy too.

The service was great and quick, too. And friendly!!!! Plus 1 star.

I'll be back. and back. and back again.
author: Francesca F.

description:
Lettuce in pho is deeply disturbing to me. While nothing else was particularly wrong about my bowl of pho ga, it was tough to get over the lettuce. My dining partner was mistakenly given a bowl of seafood pho and we had to haggle with the server before we could get what he actually ordered - pho with brisket. 

The cha gio here is great - and it is with these wonderful imperial rolls that I really could have used the lettuce, rather than in my soup!

If you're planning to go "golden" in Chinatown make it Golden Star, not Golden Flower.
author: Miriam W.

description: Their foods are really Delicious. I fall in love hue spicy beef noodle, it's maybe one of the best in SF. Located in Chinatown and next to 2 awesome Chinese restaurant, Golden flower Vietnamese restaurant is not a wrong decision for people who love Vietnamese food
author: Dranai N.

description: golden flower makes pretty damn good pho. Good cuts of meat, tasty broth and my friend's banh mi was enormous. Now i need to check out Golden Star to compare the two.
author: Misha T.

description:
vietnamese joint in sf chinatown...chinese owned of course....compact and seatings close....wondering about the hype...enter to find out...from order a disappointing start.....tossing of sprouts, leaves, jalepenos 'n' limes....definitely worst looking plate of vegetable ever seen....black and spotted...."diseased" lookin'.....another tossing of oversized large (roughly $six) pho order....standard tastes of broth, bit darker in color than norm...decent tasting.....but, clumps of cold pre-boiled noodles tossed in broth...another minus to this patron....sloppy presentation thought....imperial rolls small and okay tasting....but, one lettuce leaf?@#!#?@!??....disappointing, but filling meal....

spicy beef noodle soup seems to be the new favorite here...and, would recommend spicy beef noodle soup over the standard pho....
author: Hen A.

description:
This is my new favorite Vietnamese place in the city.  The prices are very fair and the food is very good.... the most amazing thing was that the service was pretty good... for China Town it was VERY good!  

I had the grilled pork with rice and imperial rolls.  I loved the whole dish!  The only thing I would avoid here is the tea... It was a bit strong... almost as if it was fresh from another table... with more hot water added.
author: John F.

description:
The secret to good pho is good broth.
It's really the heart of finding good pho in this town. And these guys definitely hit the nail on the head. The broth is rich, hot, filled with character. Some places in town serve watered-down nonsense. Others don't come hot enough. Golden Flower definitely sets a new standard in my pho quest.
If you've been looking for a steaming bowl of noodles to accompany you on those cold and rainy afternoons, Golden Flower is a hot pick.
author: Rhys A.

description:
Golden Flower was probably one of the first Vietnamese restaurants I ever went to back in high school.  I found in again when I started working downtown and would venture through Chinatown during my lunch breaks.  I found myself here last night for dinner.

I usually stick with the pho, and this time I went for #1, the "special combo with rare slices of steak, well-done brisket, flank, tendon, and tripe".  It's considered the X-Large bowl at $5.50 and there are beef balls in this order too.  My friend had the #3, which according to the menu, was the Large size and it costs the same.  The only difference was that he didn't have beef balls in his.  I don't usually go for the X-Large, usually content with the Regular size more often than not.  I was starving last night and it was damn cold.  Well, it looked like a large too me and I wasn't particularly full when I left.  I guess when the price doesn't reflect an X-Large, then you shouldn't really expect one then, huh?  

Overall, it was pho as you would expect it.  Nothing spectacular about it or bad either.  They seem a bit cheap on the beansprouts though, and I would have preferred more.  And you have to ask for extra napkins at this Vietnamese restaurant because they only put one out for you.  (And if you like to add that hot sauce in there, you're going to be needing more with a runny nose like me!)

Sidenote: The restroom is hidden away in the back and down the stairs.  Cash only!
author: Teri C.

description:
Decent food at a reasonable price.

Eaten multiple times and the service is usually good, actually improved from when I first came here.  The food is not outstanding but for the price it is a good option for some Vietnamese in the Chinatown area.  The #1 is the house special pho and probably the best value.  Never had a bad meal here.
author: Jay A.

description:
Had the #48. It was a chicken leg and imperial roll rice plate. Around $7.50 and came with enough food to fill me up after a day of walking. I was pretty exhausted after walking from 20th and Folsom and up to Chinatown, but this plate was just the perfect meal. The chicken was juicy and flavorful, yet the dish was light enough that I was able to continue walking without having to waddle. 

I'm not sure I'll ever return here as a destination, but if I'm in the area and craving Vietnamese I'll likely stop by.
author: Curtis B.

description:
My waitress reminded me of the prostitute in Full Metal Jacket, 40+ years later and all. Me love you OLD time.

Now for the review. Against my better judgement, I opted to have Vietnamese in Chinatown. It was a mistake. Had the pho tai. The noodles were lumpy and it was an effort to pull them apart. The broth wasn't hot and rather bland.  Stingy beef portions and no jalapeños? Really? Two Vietnamese girls who sat across from me felt the same way.  Awful.
author: John T.

description:
I  desperately want to find a perfect Pho in SF.  I could find an OK pho in SF but not a great one.  I can make better Pho at home but I don't have 6 hours to cook beef bone (oxtail etc) and spices (Cloves Saigon cinnamon, star anise, cloves, and cardamom seeds).    

Pho at Golden Flower is an OK.  Their broth is tasty but aroma of star anise is too strong for my taste.   For the toppings, the rare stakes were not bad quality meat but were sliced too thick.   The brisket was tender and testy but had yellow fat (which I do not like) on the side.  The meat balls were smaller size (I like that) and well flavored but had chunks of tripe/tendon in it (I prefer smooth kind).

Overall they are a tie with Pho Tan Hoa
author: Chie J.

description:
I Liked this place, didn't want to review it cause didn't want to share this place to anyone, haha

Have to admit the food is not the most delicious kind of food.., the service is not the nicest, but they are very attentive and the food arrived real fast. They taste like regular pho...and I love pho, and here, the food is fresh and they serve quick!, and it's not pricy at all....
I  think, this is not a place where you would drive all the way to eat, but if you happened to live near by or that you have/ need to have a regular visit to chinatown, this is definitely the place to have a quick lunch.
author: Kristin W.

description:
I was expecting this place to be really good because of the Yelp reviews and it's placed right in Chinatown!  But I was a bit disappointed.  I got the vermicelli with shrimp and grilled pork.  The sauce wasn't anything special.  The bowl could've used more mints.  The noodles were bigger than usual.  The shrimps had no flavor.  Overall, it just didn't taste fresh.

The food was alright though.  It just wasn't spectacular.  However, I will still eat there if I'm in the area.  Pretty cheap and there's a wide selection.  The staff is nice and I like the hot tea!
author: D N.

description: This place is phenomenal. I don't know why there are negative reviews! I'm korean and I've had a loooot of pho before and I've even travelled to Vietnam and had authentic pho there. This place's pho is BURSTING with flavor and is so filling! Even the smaller bowl. The pice point is perfect-suuuuper affordable. The Vietnamese coffee is also fresh and obviously just as delicious.
author: Sejin J.

description:
This place is okay nothing special about this place. First walking in there a heater next to the door. Really! What the point of putting the heater near the door? I guess the owner don't care about customer's safety. The lighting was crappy at best. Decided to get the Pho and the imperial roll. The sauce that come with the roll doesn't fresh look like it was from a previous customer. The taste of the roll was not fresh, it taste like it was heavy. The Pho was OK, the noodle come out in a big lump and it took five min in order to break the lump up. The person who took our order, I think he mixed our order up Overall:
 it was filling for the price.
author: Chris Y.

description:
This WAS my favorite place to get pho for a long ass time(10+ years, i think). I didnt even mind coming all the way to chinatown for it. I remember taking the bus with my mom in middle school just to eat pho. I believe I had my first bowl of pho here. I would always compare other pho places to this one. 
BUT WHAT HAPPENED!?!? WHAT HAPPENED TO YOUR FLAVORFUL BROTH? WHY DID YOUR PORTIONS SHRINK? WHAT DID THOSE NEW OWNERS DO TO YOU? 

Now I have no reason to come to this area. :'(
author: Stacy L.

description:
Nothing's better than a hot bowl of VEGETABLE pho. Haha..Ok I know most of you are probably rolling your eyes. But if you are trying to have a light healthy lunch then order it this way:

Small/Med Veggie Pho : with regular tofu (not fried); and substitute the broth they use for the beef broth. It is absolutely my favorite! I normally don't like to eat a heavy lunch so this is a perfect lunch time meal!

Now for all you meat lovers: My husband is the same way he laughs at me every time I request for all veggie. He'll have his usually pho with EVERYTHING oh and yes LARGE please. I swear he could live off this stuff and he says Golden Flower does it the best. The broth is so flavorful and always piping hot!

Try it for yourself.....soooo good and soooo cheap lunch for the two of us $13 (thats with tip included!)
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Fav place to eat pho in San Francisco. 
The apsmosphere is great, although I wouldn't recommend you sitting right next to the door or at least close the door, because the wind just hits you right in the face. Food's good, never had any problems with it. The Broth was heaven :3
My only complain is the place is kinda small fits only about 40ish people.
And the restroom is placed in an awkward place. Seems like someone would kidnap you. But it's like that in most restaurant in Chinatown.
I always eat with my friends here after volunteer for the street fairs in Chinatown. They give you discounts too.
author: Lilian C.

description:
Best Pho in SF that we have found so far.

We like our soup with not much MSG and a good clean taste.  Not sweet.  Not salty. This is the place to go.  I know all the talk about the other Golden place, but I just don't like the MSG there.

Good chicken pho.  Good beef pho and great imperial rolls.  Nice tidy little place that's always packed at lunch time. 

Watch your step when you go to the underground bathroom.  One mis-step and you can kiss your as... good bye.
author: Andy L.

description:
This is my number one Pho restaurant when I come to China town.  I use to come here every Saturday for lunch before Chinese school and during my lunch break when I use to work at the Embarcadero center.  

PHO & the FRIED EGGROLLS  is what keeps me coming back here.  The soup base is rich and tasty,. not watered down like most places.   Pricing is CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP and they get packed during peak hours (i.e LUNCH esp).  The traffic in the restaurant moves fast though.  I suggest arriving at 11:30 am so you can beat the crowd.

I see Pho Restaurants as a Vietnamese fast food joint,..   People order, eat and leave.

Utensils are kind of icky,. so make sure you wipe em down with napkins and hot teaaa!
author: Chanel L.

description:
There are many pho places in Chinatown, but none are as up to par as Golden Flower. I used to eat here many times, with friends and my girlfriend. In fact, it was this very restaurant that I took my girlfriend out on our first date! (I will bear no shame in this fact, as there's a funny story behind this..)

Their portions are generous and just right for a ravenous beast like me. There are multiple choices of meat, and each are cooked just right. The noodles are real pho noodles not some chow mein looking noodles at other Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown. The staff is also very nice and tend to your every needs.

The most attractive thing about this place other than the food, would be the price. While other Vietnamese noodle shops around the area charge you close to $9 - $10, this place keeps your wallet happy by keeping it close to $7 - $8. Don't think because it's so cheap, that the quality goes down with it, it's not true! 

I loved coming to this place for pho and it ranks #2 on my top Vietnamese noodle shops in the city (the other being in Tenderloin). I would definitely return more often if my girlfriend had not offered me free pho at her place.. Haha. (Funny story behind this..)
author: Jacky P.

description: An average Pho place.  We usually get those shrimp+pork rolls, which tasted good, my friend goes with beef soup and I get BBQ chicken, but for a change experimented #43 (golden flower special seafood noodle).  Instead of seafood I requested them to add chicken and the veggies showed in the display pic.  It comes with crispy noodle and I should warn people who prefer to stay away from fried noodle, please stay way AWAY from their crispy noodle lol.  Also they have noodle section with chow fun entry, but they dont serve chow fun anymore.. The good part is that the portion of the food is pretty much decent for the price they offer.
author: Hema K.

description:
This place gets really busy during around lunch time during the work week, so be prepared to wait some time or share tables. Everything arrives quickly and fresh from the kitchen, so even if you waited a good 5-7 minutes before you sit down, you'll definitely make it back to work in a timely fashion. 

I had a bad experience only once while dining here and it was a gross hair in my grilled five-spice chicken vermicelli noodle bowl (bun). However, they quickly took it away and replaced it with a new bowl. I admit, I was still grossed out. I go back to this place, though, because it's really cheap and you definitely leave satisfied. I don't order the five-spice chicken vermicelli noodle bowl though.
author: NickJess S.

description:
Another "Golden" named Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown I had lunch at. I still had my everything Pho. It was pretty solid. One thing I want to suggest is to have a bit better lighting. It's a bit dim. When it comes to pho, for some reasons I like to have it in bright light.

One thing I found about takeout and eat in at the 3 places is that the food tends to be more for takeout. But the experience to have it in a giant ceramic bowl with that scented steam broth going through the nose instead of the plastic tall container is simply unbeatable.

I always love to have the pho at the restaurant but get the coffee in a to-go cup because there's no way you can wait for the coffee to drip completely and also drink until the ice is gone within 45 minutes. So it's best to take the coffee with you, to extend the consumption of some very strong chicory coffee.
author: T L.

description: Best egg-cream soda in San Francisco! (#5 on the drink menu, misspelled Youk) You just have to put up with the owner yelling at you "That drink is for pregnant ladies, ha ha ha! Makes skin very smooth!" Whatever. I know an egg-cream when I see one and it makes me nostalgic for the Catskills. Shut up and let me enjoy.
author: Mulberry S.

description:
Initially I didn't want to come all the way to Chinatown just for pho, but the look in my brother's eyes when he said "I'LL PAY FOR PARKING." sparked a curiosity that I just couldn't resist. Golden Flower is the bomb.com for pho in the city. I've passed by this place a thousand times and for some reason never thought of going in. From the outside (well, and inside) it looks like just any other hole in the wall restaurant in Chinatown. But what a diamond in the rough this place is. There is a reason why this place is always packed with people, the food is good. I LOVE the broth. It may be a tad salty for some people, but my Chinese taste buds were dancing with joy with the first spoonful. Not to mention, the prices are cheaps! Definitely a refreshing sight when most prices at other pho places have been going up. 

I think I just found my favorite pho spot in the city! Oh hay nao!
author: Jen L.

description:
I've been to the other "Golden"s in Chinatown and this is the best one. The food is the best, portions generous and the service is fast and not creepy (we walked into Golden Star and had 4 Vietnamese women stare at us while we ate our food. I guess they were eager to clear the plates?)

I've had the pho, imperial rolls, the Vietnamese rice wraps and a couple other noodle dishes. Oh, and Thai iced tea! All were quite yummy! Prices are pretty good too, I think a small pho (which is what I get) is $5.75 and a big one is a little over $6. I get the small one only because I love drinking ALL the broth! Thai Iced teas are $2.50? They go so well with the pho because I always end up adding a littttle too much sriracha.

Anyways, service is fast too, you walk in and sit wherever you want, and somebody brings you hot tea. Pho always comes out quick cuz it doesn't need much cooking. Credit cards are accepted, which is AWESOME. And lastly, the owner lady at the counter is lovely.
author: Emily H.

description:
A Vietnamese Restaurant actually owned by Vietnamese people?  That's a rarity in Nor Cal (excluding San Jose).  

As I come from the Land of Westminster, I know my Vietnamese food and is a bit picky.  

But the pho here is good and passable, makes for a cheap and filling lunch!  It could use a bit more meat in the pho though.  My friend's Pork noodle bowl also looked good and he liked it as well.  

The food is 3.5 stars but I'll bump it up to 4 just because of the authenticity (I mean they have Bun Bo Hue, which is hard to find even at these so call "Vietnamese" restaurants)
author: Alex T.

description:
I have been to this place dozens of times.  It's my favorite Pho in the neighborhood.  The broth is nicely beefy and well spiced and seasoned.  

The other Vietnamese dishes are solid.  But it's the Pho that stands out for me.  Although, I do have a soft spot in my heart for Imperial Roll Bun.  Hard to go wrong with hot tasty fried bits on top of cold noodles and crunchy veggies, with a deep salty sweet fish sauce.  

Now that I don't work in the neighborhood, I miss this place terribly.  

N.B. To prevent the rare sliced beef from overcooking, ask for it on the side.  Also save room for dessert, because the Golden Gate Bakery is just around the corner.
author: Daniel B.

description:
Good ol' Ben Franklin once said (I am paraphrasing here); "the only things certain in life are death and taxes."

But I think they should revise that saying; "the only things certain in life are death, taxes and that the first item listed at any Vietnamese restaurant menu will be a XL bowl of beef pho." 

When you say the #1 at any pho restaurant they know exactly what you mean. It is something that is understood by all.

This is pretty true at all pho restaurants. There is nothing wrong with going to this classic dish (or maybe I should say bowl). No one faults you for picking a classic. It is comfort food through and through. But I am not here to comment on the pho or the spring rolls served at this restaurant.

For lunch I decided to forgo getting the #1 and instead settled on their Rare Beef Salad (the #30). And to my pleasant surprise this was absolutely delicious. They served thinly sliced pieces of beef dressed in lemon juice (with a side of fish sauce), fresh greens, and a heaping pile of roasted peanuts. It reminded me of a carpaccio dish, but a lot cheaper ($7) and without the snobbery. 

My only knock on this dish is that it is kind of small. I am use to eating things from an XL bowl, so getting just a small plate full of food didn't seem to do it for me. 

Is the #30 my new #1?!  It just might be. 

Despite the high praise for the #30, this place still only gets 3 stars from me. If it looks like a pho restaurant, smells like a pho restaurant, and has sticky tables like a pho restaurant, it is still just your typical pho restaurant.
author: Allan Y.

description:
Golden F., you're a star...four stars to be exact.

During the nonstop, when-am-i-going-see-the sun again rainy wintery week, my tummy craved their imperial rolls over noodles and my mom craved their five spice chicken.

So during one of the stormiest nights, I ventured here for my folks and placed our order. The kind patroness bestowed a steamin' cup of tea while I patiently waited and dried out.  15 minutes later, our food was bagged and ready to go.  3 meals for about $20...still reasonable.

15 minutes later at home, we tucked in; the imperial rolls over noodles and veggies were crispy and hit the spot, my dad inhaled his beef pho and my mom's eyes popped at seeing her beloved five spice chicken all dressed up just for her.  It was one of the quietest meals we had; we were too busy eating.

GFVR, thanks for being a stellar and great cheap eats for us.
author: Jen L.

description:
There's nothing special about this Vietnamese restaurant. It's the regular hot bowl of Pho noodles kind-of-joint. The service is similar to any other Viet restaurant; they take order, present food and let you be. Some people like it, some don't.

The thing that bothers me is the kind of atmosphere and comfort while you are there. More than often, lunch time at this place can get pretty crowded. Who am i kidding?! The location in Chinatown offers tight walking space with elbow-to-elbow dining. Maybe it's just me, but we always get seated on the left side of the restaurant. 

If you have a cold, don't come here! The place is only so big and once the door opens, you will know when it opens! Overall, food not bad. Just expect it to be small and crowded.
author: Helen T.

description: Decent, not great.   Another words, it's good enough to satisfy my craving.  I'd rather eat McDonald's than have bad pho.    They do use a bit too much MSG but so do most Pho places.   Still haven't found a great Pho place in SF that compares to garden grove/Bolsa California.
author: Loc V.

description: Me and my best friends favorite gathering place. The food is good, the staff is excellent. We went there so much that the staff doesn't even need to take our orders, they just bring our order straight to us! They remember that I love to drink ice water so they bring that right away. If you are someone looking for a cheap and fulfilling vietnamese meal, this is definitely the place! Don't forget to try their thai ice tea! Theee Best!
author: Linda K.

description: How happy was I to pick up a weekend gig in Chinatown? HEAVEN! With so much Asian food to choose from, I still gravitated towards Vietnamese...and mainly towards all things Pho. Kudos to ANY Vietnamese spot that'll let me pay for my bowl of heaven with cards. I just don't carry that much cash on me on a day-to-day...and those Pho cravings (although frequent) can come outta nowhere! I quickly became a frequent customer here for their location, for their credit-friendly option, and of course, for their food! Their broth could use a little more time with preparation (boiling bone marrow), but still well-flavored. I'm not too impressed with their imperial rolls, but I still consume every bite. Prices are reasonable, as with most Vietnamese restaurants. Overall, I am always satisfied with my meal.
author: Helen L.

description: I used to like coming here, but my last experience has changed my mind. My bf and I ordered pho and hot and sour soup. My order of hot and sour soup came out with a long black hair in it. I immediately informed my waitress and she took it away. Due to my time constraints, I decided to change my order and get egg rolls instead. After we scarfed down the egg rolls, we realized that there was another hair on the bottom of the plate. I informed my waitress again and she didn't charge me for the egg rolls, but I will not be coming back! 2 hairs in 1 meal, not a way to do business especially in a city filled with great Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Naomi C.

description: Any real fan of good tasting Vietnamese food will know that this place is not very authentic in taste at all! I ordered the seafood rice noodle soup and got what tasted like a pho beef noodle broth with some lettuce leafs floating around in it. Highly disappointed!
author: Nick D.

description: This was my go-to Pho place in Chinatown. Cheap, quick, tasty, and perfect for the cold and foggy SF day.
author: Ruth H.

description:
Now that the Saigon restaurant is sadly out of business, I HAD to find a place to get my fix of grilled pork & imperial rolls over vermicelli.  Luckily, I didn't have to search high and low, but simply hiked a up the hill (Jackson) and found Golden Flower.

It is usually buzzing with activity during the lunch hour, but I've never had a problem getting a seat. 

The pork is tender and tasty, and their imperial rolls while not as massive as Saigon's used to be, are right on!  I leave there plenty satisfied and have brought a couple friends here too, and they were happy campers too.  Mission accomplished!
author: Evelyn K.

description: Good food. If you're craving Vietnamese in CT, this is the place to go. Small little place, good food, that's all you need anyways.
author: Lily W.

description:
One of my favorite Vietnamese places to eat, especially when you find yourself stuck in Chinatown. Love their Pho and Vermicelli dishes. 

I'm not into their rice dishes since I'd rather have the Vermicelli instead. But not much difference in rice or noodle dishes. Very good grilled meats and their imperial rolls are great. 

Love the Iced Vietnamese coffee here. Made fresh and always have it ready for me to-go. Enjoy!
author: Nana R.

description:
Golden Flower - I love you for things other than your pho. Your pho is only mediocre and I do not ever eat my beloved pho there with Golden Star down the block. But that does not mean there is not good food to be had. I do enjoy your grilled pork and vermicelli dishes. When I am not in the mood for pho, you are my go to. Bun Thit Nuong Cha Goi is my go to there and that is why I give you 4 stars. Fresh veggies, and standard noodles, but great meat (though sometimes a little fatty) and good rolls (though not much differentiation there in regards to others in the area. 
I also like your service. Your old owner would always greet me with a warm smile, but alas she is back in Vietnam. Still, I like the feelign I get when I eat there, like its just another home.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Gotta try the rare beef, appetizer. It's kinda like Carpaccio but Vietnamese style. Rare beef topped with peanuts, cilantro, green onion, white onion and lemon juice. It comes with the fish sauce on the side. I rarely see this on the menu at the other pho restaurants. The sweetness of the beef and onion go so well together. 

A large pho here = large bowl not the portion of food. But... I'm a girl, so I think the small is just right for me. Overall, I think the appetizers here are awesome!
author: Christina W.

description: Excellent food friendly service no ambiance. But I was was there for the food.  Menu was large. I believe the chef and workers were Chinese.
author: shelley s.

description: A favorite of my co-workers for good (great!) lunch pho. Also the spring rolls are phenom. Quick, easy, delicious and won't murder your available balance.
author: Helen S.

description:
Imperial rolls were the best I've ever had. Chewy and not greasy. The rare steak pho was also really good. 

an extra star for being the ONLY really tasty restaurant I've found in chinatown (i live nearby). ok, I also like LaLola. BUT, is there ANY good chinese food in chinatown?
author: Claire b.

description: Super fast, super fun, and super yum! There is nothing better than some amazing Pho to end a cold day in the city.
author: Mike P.

description:
The pho is only okay, not that great. The noodles are always kinda hard like it's undercooked or something.
But the rice plates are good. I like their chicken with egg plate.
I use to go here all the time with my dad when I was a little kid.
When I got to high school I started going to Golden King which is way better. This place has less choices than Golden King.
author: Annie H.

description:
The stories are true and there's no other cliche of a tale to share other than... "I walked into this hole on the wall place and found the best food ever."

As my future wife and I were walking around on Chinatown's biggest day - Chinese New Year Parade, we found this place. All the other hotspots that were rated highly on yelp were closed for lunch and preparing for dinner, but not this place. 

I had a vermicelli dish with beef and imperial rolls. It was fantastic! Its a small business - much like the rest of the neighborhood. Service was quick. You also know the place is authentic, not only for it's neighborhood but the fact that some of the staff do not speak english.

Get off this website right now and head over there with a friend. This food must be shared!
author: Noe F.

description:
I decided to try this place out because of the high ratings on Yelp, because Yelpers generally don't steer me in the wrong direction.

I shared the Imperial rolls with my BF, pretty good, but not fantastic.  He had the rare beef pho and I was looking so forward to it from all the glowing reviews; however, I was disappointed.  I expected it to be a mind-blowing, flavor party on my tongue, but alas... nothing.  No depth of flavor, no party on my tongue and the meat was kind of weird.  I totally wussed out and got a basic chicken with broccoli, so I am not judging my stars on my dish because it was my fault for being boring, but this dish was not good either.  The sauce had very little flavor and the chicken was tender, but had a lot of chewy parts, which left me not wanting to finish it. 

Maybe I will try it again.  I will say the service was pretty fast and it was definitely one of the cheaper meals I have had in the city.  Maybe it was just an off night?
author: Amy J.

description: I just got away from the warm and humid weather in Vietnam, a week before. Then found myself here for a hot bowl of pho on a chilly day in the city. I did come here to satisfy my pho bo vien (pho with beef balls/meatballs) since I didn't come across it on my trip. I must say that the pho in SF and Hanoi (Pho 10) are almost identical. Taste wise they are the same. The only difference is the portion and price. But I doubt you'll find be able to find a bowl of pho in SF for $1.75USD lol.
author: Jen P.

description:
i finally stopped in for the bun bo hue. a really unassuming pho place with construction blocking the front and obscuring it more--but the large red lettering by the front door touting bun bo hue caught my eye.

it's pretty tasty, not the best by any means (where's the lemongrass?? cmon people, bun bo hue should be a punch in the stomach of flavor flavor and more flavor!!) but it's passable. the real winner is that it's a huge portion at only $7.75. i'll be back, may try the pho ($6.55) if i get bored of the bun.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Four stars because I absolutely loved the rare beef Pho I got here, but until I've had built more of a foundation for comparison, I don't feel right about giving the fifth star yet. (I am not a Pho snob.)

Restaurant was small and clean, with a mom & pop feel. Price was very reasonable, and portions were generous. All ingredients (lime, basil leaves, sprouts, noodles, cilantro, and rare beef) were very fresh and crisp, and served in perfect proportions, contrary to what I've received in other soup containers where they really skimp on the good stuff.
author: Heidi G.

description:
I have a crazy Chinese coworker who makes me walk from Beale and Market to Telegraph Hill, up the Filbert Steps to Coit Tower, and then down to this place.

If the chicken noodle dish wasn't so good, I'd have killed him by now.
author: Mike G.

description:
This will be for sure my go to place for Pho in the city from now on!  Well if I am around Chinatown that is.  First the flavors - so good.  Fresh ingredients and the chicken pho that I had was delish!!  

Had the egg rolls which were great as well - not too greasy and very well made veggie imperial rolls for sure! When I went it was a late lunch so it was nice and quiet and of course the service was quick and very friendly.  I will for sure be back to this place not only for all of these things I just mentioned but also because it was the cheapest meal I have had in months!!  Very reasonable indeed!  Check this place out for sure if you have the opportunity to venture into Chinatown and have the hankering for some yummy Pho!
author: Heidi S.

description:
Overall: B
What's not to like about this place? Yummy and cheap. Nuff said

Food: B
Tasty and filling. Actually, belt busting filling. If you're getting the pho skip the appetizers. Unfortunately, no alcohol. 

Value: A
Huge portions with cheap prices.

Service: B
We ordered 2 bowls of  pho and it came out in about 5 minutes. 


Decor: C
Bare bones simple.
author: Roger H.

description: Extremely affordable, great pho restaurant. Friendly staff and good friend. Conveniently located near the Financial District, Chinatown and North Beach.
author: Julie F.

description: I'd give them 5 stars if the meat wasn't tough or chewy. I am not sure how bun bo hue is SUPPOSED to taste like but I was craving for this dish for days and when I came here to eat it, it satisfied every single one of my taste buds. (Even my lips) It was spicy.. more spicy than I thought but it was gooooooood. I LOVED the broth but couldn't drink most of it since it would take up space in my stomach. I had to save the room for the noodles. Something about the soup and the noodles that were my favorite part of the whole dish. Okay, I lied, I love the veggies more but thats because I love my veggies. YOU MUST TRY THIS PLACE!!!. Photo posted. My bestie had the pho dac biet and she had her pho craving satisfied too :D
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Everything was very good, including the service and attentiveness of the waitstaff.  I had the Stir-fried beef on one visit.  It was that good, I had to return the following day and had the Sizzling chicken with vegetables.  I found that the one thing that was most awesome were sauteed chicken rolls wrapped in rice paper, probably one of the most popular items on the menu.  The menu has not changed over the past few years but what can I say?  The food is very inexpensive, a small "hole-in-the-wall" establishment in Chinatown, but if your looking for a 5-Star dining experience with exceptional service, hostess, a reservation, linen tablecloths/napkins, this is most definitely not the place for you...
author: Isaac G.

description: Fresh rolls, ok. Spicy pork with lemongrass, delicious but not spicy enough.
author: Johann R.

description:
My family and I wandered into the restaurant, cold and hungry. The chicken noodle soup that I ordered was delicious. The soup was hot and savory. My sister got some seafood soup with egg noodles, and my dad got some noodles with beef soup. Surprisingly, unlike other Vietnamese Pho restaurants that I had went to, all the soups had their own distinct, tasty flavor. They had good sized portions, and the food came out in no less than ten minutes. The restaurant size was small, but cozy.
The only thing that downgrades this review to four stars, is it's lack of hygiene. To go to the bathroom, I found that I had to go down some steep stairs into a basement, which smelled pretty nasty. It was wet and slippery down there, but fortunately, the bathroom wasn't too dirty.
author: Breanna L.

description: So far, in my hunt for the best bowl of Pho in SF, this place is my favorite. It's authentic, the broth is done right with balance and warmth, the ingredients are fresh, they give you LIMES instead of lemon (yuck) and they'll even bring you a beautifully full ramekin of freshly chopped cilantro if you ask nicely. The service is incredibly friendly, prompt, and wonderful and as an extra tip: get the pork and shrimp rolls with peanut sauce. The PERFECT starter to accompany this amazing Pho.
author: David K.

description: Holy Pho, Batman! This place is great.  Ran into it by accident and it was amazing. Great prices, service, and amazing food.
author: Sarah B.

description: This place is a hit or miss. A friend and I came here earlier today and both ordered the #1.  The waiter decides to ask us what size do we want, we're thinking in our heads, "Do you not know your own menu...? #1 is an extra-large." Apparently, he doesn't know that. When we got our food, I noticed the broth was nasty. No flavor at all, probably Loi's is even better.  While paying, the bill was 14.40 and we dropped $16 on it. When the lady gave us back our change, we only got .60 back. Where did that dollar go?? I mean, we dropped $16 for a reason, an extra $1.60 for tip. But don't try to play us and "assume" we paid $15. Probably next time when I come back, since I have a coupon, they'll give me better customer service.
author: Emily L.

description: This place is right in the heart of Chinatown, where all the Asian cuisine you can pick with all your fingers are there awaiting and I must admit, a warm bowl of pho is tempting as any on a chilly San Francisco evening. Then why the one star less? One less shining star makes all the difference between a tasty bowl of pho and a delicious bowl of pho.. I had my very first bowl of pho here when I was a child and the first owner was an amazingly genuinely kind and welcoming woman who must've boiled her water with love and secrets. I'm a fan of this place, but since my last bowl of pho, maybe more in memory but I love pho nonetheless.
author: Andy L.

description: Found this place as my friend and I were looking for some lunch in Chinatown on the weekend. Seemed pretty decent from the outside and the menu looked good. We both ordered the combination pho, but asked for it without tripe and tendon. Only $5.75 for a small, and it was pretty filling. Tasty pho! Service was pretty quick too! Wish they served cilantro with the bean sprouts though!
author: Katrina L.

description:
Ordered the pho with beef flank and brisket. The noodles were just ok. Broth was good. Flank was dry. Brisket was tasty. 

Also, had the spring rolls with shrimp and pork. These were dry, too. Not good.
author: Linda Y.

description:
I loved -- nay, lurved -- this place. I can only really compare it to Golden Star in terms of pho restaurants in the Chinatown area, but it fared really well in comparison. The food itself wasn't necessarily better, since both pho's were excellent, but we did have some additional spring rolls (#25) here which were perfect (they're hard to screw up, I guess)... and the sizes of pho #5 and pho #6 were ideal (they have some "extra large" and "large" options that I would steer clear from unless, of course, you're really into leftovers, which is a perfectly honorable desire too). 

Most importantly, however, the venue and the service were both significantly more inviting, which made all the difference. The decor is colorful and vibrant here, and the atmosphere was generally a lot more pleasant and warm so, compared to the curtness of the servers, the bareness of the locale, the plastic tables, and the fluorescent lighting of Golden Star, this was most definitely an upgrade... As were the servers, actually, which -- contrary to what many other reviewers experienced -- were polite, down-to-earth, and even, at times, genuinely kind. 

Though I'm sure there is equally good (or better) pho out there, perhaps even in the vicinity, I had such an overall fulfilling experience here that it's certainly my new favorite and I plan on going back again and again to rejoice in their pho-ness.
author: G. J.

description:
MMMM one of my favorite places for some nice pippin' hot bowls of PHO! 

Looks can be deceiving when walking in china town and you look down Jackson and see this blue overhang covered in graffiti and all you can read is PHO. But dont judge a book by it's cover my friends. 

I can never finish a "small" sized bowl.. but I always have left overs! I always get the very basic #5 - your typical beef pho. I like to mix it up once and a while with the curry or beef balls but usually I just go for the plain. What I love most is for $5.85 I can get a huge "small" bowl of delicious-ness, complimentary tea ... as much as I want, and for $2 more I can get imperial rolls. Definite good deal for a girl on a budget! 

The bathroom is an adventure in itself- you have to walk downstairs and pass by the old vietnamese ladies cooking, then theres a small area next to the bathroom with a table and a ton of boxes. I always see these men playing cards and like to think they're part of some mafia buisness...

BACK to the Pho.. delicious! And the service is always nice, and fast! Some places in san jose make me feel inferior because I'm this silly south american  girl coming into their restaurant and takes forever to get my food...not here!

Check this place out. Fo realz.
author: Amanda S.

description: People in Nor Cal don't know crap about Pho. The broth has horrible and the noodle was not cooked properly. The only plus is you get a lot of food. Service was good maybe because i was the only one there during 11 am. Just like you go to So Cal for great Mexican food, you go to Orange County for the best Pho.
author: Paul N.

description:
Although I began my pho adventures with Golden Star/King a long time ago, now I like Golden Flower more. I think the prices between the two restaurants are similar, but Golden Flower is a bit cheaper. I also think Golden Flower has more authentic flavor than G.Star. but G.Flower is considerably smaller than G.Star, so if you have a big group, G.Flower is probably not your place to go for pho. 

I would definitely come back!
author: Sam W.

description: Horrible services and they charge a lot for the amount of food you receive.  Me and my mum decided to just order #1 and just share the order between two of us because we weren't really hungry.  Right after we said we will share, the waitress told me in Mandarin "oh, you can't sit at this 4 people table, because you only ordered 1 item for both of you."  Wow, you are putting a price take on us by how much we order and does each table has it's own value depends on how much you willing to pay?  We felt really unwelcome and discriminated.   And If It is one of the rules at your restaurant, why you talked to me in Mandarin???????  We were very disgusted by that Short Hair and Mid-Aged Waitress.
author: Jade P.

description:
Every time I take a class near this place, I always have to come here for lunch. This is my favorite pho place in the city. The broth is just so amazing. When I eat pho, I usually have to douse my soup with Sriracha and hoisin sauce, but here, I actually like to savor the taste of the broth. I don't know what they do differently from other pho places, but it's what makes me come here all the time. 

Other delicious things here are the imperial rolls. Mmm. And the fresh lemonade.
author: Paweena P.

description: I came to this place 3 years ago ... and it was the first time ever that I remember trying pho for the first time! I always remember this place fulled with non vietnamese people, filled with decorations, super small and compacted. But extremely c
author: Victoria L.

description:
If you are in the Entertainment Book honor the damn coupon.
