Do not come back and say "management changed"

Marcus Angry!
author: Marcus R.

description: Good food but poor service. I walked in and they ask me to sit any table and ask me what Im having before handing me a menu! So I ask for one and a woman finally came and slam it on the table. We had a party of 4 so our food took 20 min to come but the order was all mixed up. My friend ask to eggs and didn't get one. I ask for no onions but it was all over my soup???
author: Yvonnr L.

description: Having read the other reviews, I was pretty stoked about coming here...too bad I left with feelings of dread, anticipating intestinal disturbance in a few hours. Maybe I would feel differently if I hadn't asked the ill fated question, "do you have a restroom here?"  I asked against my better judgment, hoping the cramped quarters somehow concealed a clean, usable bathroom. When I walked through the kitchen, down the narrow staircase to find the bathroom, my nightmare took root. The bathroom would make a gas station look like the Four Seasons. Luckily I touched no surfaces. When the food came, I was pleasantly surprised-- it looked good, but after having seen the kitchen I was only willing to eat the BBQ beef in my bowl of bun. Beef was tasty but I couldn't get the condition of the bathroom and kitchen out of my head. I won't be going back.
author: Rosanne D.

description:
This hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese place lacks ambiance, but turns out some great pho. They have several different varieties; I tried the rare beef version which was really good. The broth was full of flavor and the accompaniments of bean sprouts, lime and jalapeno help enhance the already good flavor. 

The treat for me was the Vietnamese coffee which is served at the table in the traditional drip filter. It packed a good punch and kept me going all night!

It's VERY inexpensive too. Two of us had full dinners and drinks all for $16.
author: Lee H.

description:
I'll reserve the last star for after I check it out a few more times.  This was another hole in the wall that my boss pointed me to - and he knows his financial district restaurants.  He says it is the best of the "golden" Vietnamese restaurants, and though I haven't been to any of the others yet, this one was good.  Very crowded and people sit together at long tables.  I got a spicy squid dish which was good, and I think next time I will try the vegetarian "bun," which is like a salad with noodles mixed up with whatever meat (or non-meat) you order.  Maybe like Vietnamese bi bim bap?

update 8/3/07:  tried curried squid (good!) and vegetarian hot and sour soup (really big bowl, enough for 2 people, good, and very different than chinese hot and sour - reminds me of the way jigae is served in Korea).  also had veggie spring rolls (ehh, okay, too big to get in your mouth).  Still have to withhold 5th star - service is spotty.  I understand that this isn't Farallon, but I just about had to tackle somebody to get my check.  there was a line out the door, and you would think that they would want to open up our table, but they seemed too preoccupied to get us on our merry way.  for those that are time sensitive at lunch, i recommend getting there as early as possible, otherwise it is swamped.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Service: 3.5/5
Food: 4/5
Wait: 3/5
Price: $
Presentation of food: 4/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3/5
Overall: 4/5

THEIR IMPERIAL ROLLS ARE PRETTY CRACKINNN (:
author: Eva H.

description:
Phoget about Golden Star (they changed management couple months ago); Golden Flower is the place to go. It's a cozy, hole-in-the-wall joint with a steady flowing lunch crowd.

The food here is one of the better Vietnamese places in the city.  Less than $5 for a small bowl of pho; the broth is perfect.  Less than $6 for imperial rolls on a bed of vermicelli noodles, carrots, and bean sprouts.
author: I Love Beef C.

description: I remember coming home after my first pho here and calling up my best friend to say that I have found the one.  This is the one.  The slippery and chewy bites of vermicelli noodles, the salty and flavorful broth, the perfect proportion of meat to noodles ratio, this place is pho sho' the best pho I've ever had.
author: Linda T.

description:
I came here with my cousin when I went to get my haircut. The place is small and the portions are big. Service is nice, and keep in mind that it would be best to grab one of the big tables instead of the single 2 seat tables. Your not going to have a lot of room to eat on those small tables.

Cousin had pho with rare beef or something
I had the grilled pork with rice
and we split a order of imperial rolls

we shouldnt have ordered the rolls, cause we were way too full when we finished everything. Another place to get a bang for your buck.
author: phillip w.

description:
My co-worker wasn't kidding when she said it's better to go after 1.30p to beat the lunch rush.  

Chancing it, we arrived just after 1p and all the tables were occupied...,the staff squeezed our party of 5 around a table where 2 were chowing down.  Our hungry tummies were grateful.

I really enjoyed the food and service.  The noodles were loose (not clumpy) + cut bit-size...spared me awkwardness in front of the director.  

This place is worth the wait.
author: Cathy K.

description: Worst place ever. Horrible service never coming back again. To the short haired lady wearing pink floral shirt today you are the rudest waitress i ever met. Telling us to move when we are in the middle of eating...hell no gtfo can't we eat in peace just cause theres a bigger party coming in doesn't mean you shove us to the corner. And i wasnt even done looking at the menu so why would you take my menu without asking. We didnt do anything and you dont even give us the stuff for the pho wtf...
author: Crystal L.

description: Delicious Vietnamese comfort food.  Try the tofu with lemongrass.  Have the kitchen add broccoli for a fulfilling and healthy meal!
author: Veena D.

description: My sister and I went here while in Chinatown. Pho was great on a chilly day. We had pho dac biet and pho tai. Both were yummy! The broth was great all on its own, combined with additional seasonings and it was over the moon excellent. And the owner and staff were soooo nice. The oolong tea was also a great beverage that complimented our pho. Soooo glad. And happy to know you can get good pho in Chinatown!
author: My T.

description:
The service was dismal during our visit. Dropping off everyone else's orders at our table except for ours, taking down the order wrong, even though it's been repeated 2-3 times, unusually slow service for simple dishes, giving me the wrong entree due to taking down the wrong order, making me wait for the right order and then charging me for the wrong entree that's more expensive than the right order, and forgetting our request for water, even though we asked twice.

The food was tasty. But then it gave me what felt like dysentery. I'm still willing to give this place another shot. I'm such a masochist.
author: Trixie J.

description: Pho taste like mom's home cooking!
author: Lisa N.

description: Yum! Golden Flower and Golden King are both reliable. Golden Flower's pho broth is a bit more oniony (rather than Golden King's, which tends to be on the saltier side). But, G-Flower is always busy with loyal clientele, service is friendly, and takeout orders are fast. A very safe choice.
author: Megan G.

description: Two empty tables and wouldn't serve me because I was by myself. I do not condone poor customer service so I will not return to this restaurant.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Let me just say that the pho here is really good.  I alternate between the chicken pho and the beef pho quite often.  It's yummy yummy in my tummy.

I went here for lunch today, and am kicking myself for not just sticking with the damn pho.  I thought I'd try something new.  

I ordered their version of "shrimp chow fun" (that's basically shrimp with fat rice noodles, for the 2 people out there who don't know).

What I got were pho noodles (which are skinny) on a plate with some funky chow-fun-esque sauce and vegetables.  The veggies were good, but the noodles were gross and now I feel kinda sick. 

I will totally go back to them for their pho (quite possibly later this week), but will  never order something other than pho from them again.
author: Karen F.

description:
The pho here use to be really good- in fact, this was one of my favorite places of all time when I was a teenager, but things are different now. i'm sure it has something to do with me experiencing more of what other pho places taste like but I wasnt really impressed when i came here for lunch this afternoon. 

I ordered a #1 with beef on the side- the bowl was massive and came with a lot of noodles, although the noodles could have been a tad bit softer. The beef on the side was decent, but the pieces were sliced way too thick. The broth was alright, they kind of overdid it on the ingredients- from my opinion at least.

I use to go out of my way to come here, but after my experience today, I'll have second thoughts.
author: M W.

description:
Whenever I'm back in SF from college, this is the first place I go to for satisfying my pho cravings.

There has never been a place I've been to that's served pho that stimulates my taste buds like this restaurant. (Maybe it's MSG? Nonetheless, still amazing) I've never tried their other dishes, unfortunately, because I just want my pho fix! I always get the pho in the red broth or Number 1, both very tastey and savory soups, you'll want to drink all the broth. Sometimes the meat can be on the fatty side. Service is uber expedient, they know how to bust out the soups; you won't be waiting half an hour for your meal or the check. The bathrooms are a bit worn, but they're better than public restrooms. GREAT prices, you can't beat it!
author: Selina C.

description: You may be asking yourself, is this place pho real? The answer is yes....stop in around noon on a weekday and you'll be greeted with a packed dining room. The community table option means you won't have to wait more than 15 minutes, even at peak lunch hour. There's nothing cozy about this place, except for the feeling a big bowl of pho leaves you with. The chicken pho comes with a rich and satisfying broth, the accompanying limes, mint, and jalapeños are always super fresh, and the chicken meat is surprisingly tender and completely skin- and cartilage-free. The vegetable pho is slightly lacking in flavor, but makes up for it with loads of fresh vegetables. The imperial rolls are so-so. The waiters are brisk, but pleasant enough. At $7.50 for a teeming bowl of hearty pho, this place can't be beat. They also offer generously portioned pho take-out. I also find it convenient that you can walk in at the odd hours of 10am or 3:45pm, for example, and order take out or eat in.
author: Emma R.

description:
Let me provide context here:  every city that I go to, I look for Vietnamese food.  Whether it be San Francisco, Miami, New York or Sydney; I love the stuff.  I have beef broth in my veins.

In SF alone, I've braved the holes on Clement St., the delicacies on Irving St., downtown, Saigon City in San Mateo.  You name it, I've tried it.

For the record, this place has the BEST PHO I've had.  

What makes a good pho you ask?  Two very simple things:

1.  The flavor of the soup stock.

If the soup stock is not BEEF based, walk away my friend (have you ever had pho where the stock is chicken based?  Those places should be ashamed of themselves).

If the soup stock is not at least slight murky, leave immediately.  This is one of the few places that I will actually drink the stock until my bowl is empty.

2.  The heat of the soup stock.

When you order pho with rare slices of beef, you should be able to submerge the slices for one minute and have them cook in the stock.

The service is that of an Asian restaurant.  You will get your food when you do and you will like it.

The other food beside the pho?  How the hell would I know?  Just get the pho, smart ass.

Weekdays for lunch gets very crowded.  Expect to wait if you show up after 12 noon.  I've never had any issues waiting during dinner time or on weekends.
author: Deron D.

description: Great place to grab some classic pho' noodle soup. Not to far away from the Financial District.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Obey the heed of no one who suggests Golden Star, aka Thumb Soup (you figure it out). Golden Flower is a pho (that's pronounced fuuuuuuh, with a bit of a tonal upturn at the end) delight. I'd format my Vietnamese, but this isn't MySpace.

Charming staff, and you can go to the Matsu temple in the alley across the street while you wait. 

If you don't know who Matsu is, don't worry; she knows you. Wear a life preserver. 

Anybody who goes to Golden Star is just kidding themselves.
author: Sean K.

description:
I use to love this place when I was a kid, but this place has really gone down in the dumps recently.  The last time I came here, I remember their beef tasting really weird...almost old.  It did not taste fresh atttt all.  Their soup wasn't as rich tasting as I remembered.  

I'm sad to say that I no longer visit this establishment.  I'd rather go to golden star.
author: LiveToEat F.

description:
Used to come here alot when my wife worked in the area.  Afterwork, I'd pick her up and we'd come here for a quick dinner.  Portions are good, prices are good, food is good.  Fast Service.  It'd usually be dead right at 5pm but that's actually good cause no waiting.  

Nothing to complain about.  We'd be in and out quickly and would have plenty to time to relax once we get home...
author: Mark W.

description:
A few nights ago, my husband and I were heading home, cranky, tired and hungry.  In an attempt to save money and eat at home more, we were driving home through Chinatown when "Golden Flower Pho!" popped into both our heads.  It was 9:10pm and we didn't know if they closed at 9:30pm so we drove quickly and found rockstar parking half a block down the street.  There were still customers inside but when we got to the door, the sign read "9:00am - 9:00pm".  We stepped in anyway and the proprieter lady waved us to a table (YAY!)  We'd been here once before and eaten something other than the pho so this time we went straight for the pho:  #7: rare steak and beef balls LARGE for me and Pho Ga - chicken pho for him, also LARGE.

Tea was served immediately and about 5 minutes later, 2 giant, steaming, bowls of pho were placed in front of us.  

I don't know how they do it, the beef pho had abotu 6 good-looking pieces of steak, pink in the middle and lots of large beef balls.  The soup was so comforting and really hit the spot.  Of course, I topped it with beansprouts, lemon and peppers and sprinked the Siracha over the soup.

I hate it when meat has dangly bits of fat and tendons and other oddities on it but the meat in both our bowls was nice and clean.  There was a generous amount of shredded chicken in the Pho Ga and some lettuce which would have been really good if there wasn't some brown bits on the edge - we picked that out.

Soon the restaurant started to clear out, the proprieter making conversation with the last trickle of customers.  As they cleaned up, we hurried to finish our piping hot soup - but she called out to us to take our time and even topped up our water glasses (all past closing time!!)

I love this place for having delicious, comforting broth: slightly sweet and really tasty and for being near to home.  I also like that they keep it relatively clean (sweeping the floor and wiping the chili bottles at the end of the day) and there is obviously lots of heart put into the restaurant.

I would come here 3 times a week - if I got home in time. :)  at a previous visit, my husband got the 5 spice chicken which came with a bowl of soup noodles.  The bbq chicken was served on the side and was a fine piece of thigh meat: a never ending supply of relatively lean and clean chicken served on a lettuce leaf.  I got the bbq beef and imperial roll rice noodle which was perfect for a warm afternoon.  very refreshing!  aaah, this place is so good.  and cheap too.  $6.55 or $7.55 for large pho I think -
author: Mel L.

description: Best Pho place on my street (... possibly the only). Perfect for that rainy-day-don't-want-to-go-too-far-but-still-want-warm-soup kind of mood. They've got some interesting drinks (well, if you haven't grown up in a Chinese household) -- I'd recommend trying the lychee drink
author: Adam D.

description: Mmm yum! Rare beef pho & imperial role! Only turn off, feathers underneath my chair...why are there pigeon feathers inside?
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Somewhat dirty, but the food is solid.  We keep coming back when we're in the Chinatown area. 

I've had the nem nuong rolls (the do-it-yourself ones), banh hoi, and pho so far. 

Yum.
author: Dorothy N.

description:
Don't go here.

It's my secret place to eat delicious Pho and Bun.

But if you do go, tip. They're a nice family.
author: Eric ..

description:
Went to golden flower for lunch because new saigon was closed.  Why is this place always closed =(

Ordered Chicken noodle soup from golden flower. The chicken was dry and flavorless. It was also chewy.  Worst chicken noddle soup I have ever had.  The soup was just brown and salty.
author: Ames K.

description:
This place is awesome! Cheap, good, Pho. 
The staff is really nice and the food comes out fast. It's that perfect combo of dirty and clean. Clean pho just doesn't taste right and dirty pho is gross. 
This place gets it right.
author: Murat K.

description:
Imperial rolls are ehhh.. okay.

The LARGE Tai was a bit difficult to finish, because it was HUGE! The noodles were very delicious at first (chewy even), but not after they sat in the boiling water for too long. Yes, today's soup was definitely hot enough to cook my steak on the side. Vegetables still at high quality.
author: Elaine H.

description:
I have yet to find some better pho than what my friends Vietmanese mother makes, but this has to be a very close to it.  I am going to have to make this a regular stop now when I come back to SF.  

I had the pho and the imperial rolls.  The imperial rolls were good, but nothing compared to how good the pho actually was!  Who cares about how the place looks, its all about the food here, and they do a great job with it.

I was the only non-asian in the restaurant, but everyone was very helpful and very nice there.
author: Scott J.

description:
Golden Flower offers Quality Pho At Late Hours (QPALH). And any restaurant that scores high on the QPALH scale gets an automatic 5 stars.

I'm also giving 5 stars here because the good folks at Golden Flower know that if you're a Vietnamese restaurant, by gawd, get your pho right. And they do. I had the reliable #1 and it was huge. The price tag of $5.50 made me feel like a bandit. My wife had a simpler version of tripe with beef balls. And it was arranged more elegantly than any other bowl of pho we have ever seen. And, lemme tell ya, we've SEEN pho.

And, in the tradition of all great Vietnamese restaurants--these guys take cash only.
author: Pete L.

description:
MMMMMM ... #40. 

Grilled chicken thinly sliced ( like I like it) , noodles, fish sauce, imperial rolls.   

MMMM... #40.
author: Swiyyah W.

description:
if you're craving a bowl of pho and you work in or around the financial district, golden flower is the place to go. i always order the combo pho (#1 on the menu) and find that their broth is more flavorful and robust than the other 3-4 joints that i've tried in the area. more importantly, i'm not left with that parched, emessgeeingly gacky aftertaste. one minor gripe - they are skimpy with the jalapenos...2-3 slices; they do give you more when asked, but it's such an annoyance. hey, i'm the guy who always asks for more jalapenos, recognize!

i've also had the bun bo hue, which is very hearty but not in a barnyard kinda way.

with the exception of one young lad, the staff is borderline curt, but efficient. the dining room is kept pretty clean and seemingly hygenic.
author: Rob D.

description:
I used to come to this place all the time when i was a kid! prolly like 10-15 years ago.. and the other day i decided to eat here with my mom instead of Golden Star a block away.. (she pissed off one of the workers there so i'm afraid to show up there with her again.. haha) 

we waited over 25 minutes!! for VIETNAMESE FOOD!! which takes like what.. 10 minutes?!?! Come on.. all the other tables (who came in after us) got their food already.  I complained to the worker and then they finally brought it out.. they were saying how it takes a while to make it.. but my mom got the #1.. which is pho.. how does that take 25 minutes?! She could have just apologized and not make up some BS lie..
author: JUDY L.

description: Probably favorite place for a "#1". Soup is good, noodles are chewy, and good portion of beef. Friendly, quick service.
author: Eddy N.

description:
A very cheap and good Vietnamese restaurant. I took number 40 with chicken and the dish was good and generous.

The place is not fancy but who care? We were sited directly and just waited 10 minutes for our plates.
author: Cedric L.

description: A step below nearby Golden Star, but still very good.  I got a vermicelli bowl with pork and shrimp and loved it, minus the basil that was in there I didn't care for, but luckily, they put it all in a clump for you to mix so I was able to avoid most of it.  Their fish sauce was nice; not too fishy.  Never brought me water like I asked, but didn't mind too much since the food was good.  Spent $8 total.
author: Marc S.

description: Excellent pho, also recommend the #39 vermicelli with chicken.  Sometimes a restaurant really couldn't make any improvements without becoming more expensive, and I think this place falls into that category.
author: Andy G.

description:
gross...
should've known when we entered and there were no other customers.
we did get there at around 10am.  a young waitress with an accent greeted and seated us.  she said they'd just opened.
ok.  i have never been to a vietnamese restaurant with disgusting food.  so we stayed.  ordered vermicelli with grilled chicken and imperial rolls.
it was really salty and gross.  the bean sprouts were old and the dish contained a lot of cheap, shredded lettuce.  The chicken was pre grilled.  Um....they microwaved the meat and dumped it onto the bowls of noodles.  At least if they were going to microwave the meat, actually heat it up.  The meat was still cold.  The waitress ignored us and never refilled the teapot.  We couldn't even get her to come with the bill and the restaurant is tiny.  There was a middle-aged gentleman who worked there.  He seemed friendly and got us our bill.
author: Candy Y.

description: I love this place. Wholesome real authentic food, attentive staff and great service, reasonably priced. Handsdown the best hot and sour soup I have ever had. If you are in the area and feel a cold coming on, their hot and sour soup is a must. When they bring it to you, you might not think it is hot and sour soup because it has a clear broth, unlike most others, but it is in fact hot and sour soup.
author: Mark D.

description: Whenever I think of my happy spot it takes me back to the Golder Flower, wiping my nose---runny from the spicy steam of a perfect bowl of pho---on the sleeve of my sweatshirt, wondering if a person could survive so much happiness.
author: C.S. L.

description:
I liked this place.  It was cheap, open late, right in the heart of Chinatown.  The Pho Tai (rare beef) broth was really, very tasty.  But sadly, the meat was not the best ever.  Kind of fatty and tough.  It wouldn't matter so much if I was hard core like Richard K and ate the tripe and tendon pho.  But I'm not there yet, so it's important that my beef slices are good quality, since that's the main attraction.  But on a more positive note, I think Richard was really happy with his Pho-for-the-Brave, and the spring rolls were delicious and very fresh.  Much bigger than the average spring roll, too.  Love that.  

BTW, it's pronounced FUH.
author: Kerrinski S.

description:
***Edited 3/4/2008***
Waaaaahhh. Ok. I am taking off a few stars. What happened top their pho??? It has no flavor!  What the buck, do? (Vietslang accent)

Still good for bun, but the pho was so yucky last time! :o(
_____________________________________________

Listen To This Vietnamese Map Dit Girl: It's Good
Oh thank you Golden Flower for being a beacon of fresh Vietnamese food in sauce- and old grease and fortune cookie-laden Chinatown! Golden Flower passes the test with flying colors for basic, tasty, cheap and fresh Vietnamese standards. Just look at all the straight black hair around you- my criteria for trying a new Asian place: lots of straight black hair inside. If I keep going here for lunch my dit is really going to be map. (Map Dit= Fat Butt in Vietnamese).
author: Jackie P.

description: This popular restaurant is nearly always busy,Fresh food, fast service, cheerful atmosphere, open late, great prices
author: Nicole R.

description: Best 5 spice chicken with pho in the city.  I love this place, and the owners are very nice.  I eat here any time that I am near Chinatown, and often make special trips down there just to get my pho fix.
author: W B.

description: Big bowl of pho. $7. Friendly service.
author: Yelpy S.

description:
I don't know what they put into their pho, but the soup is extremely tasty!  This is the place I go whenever I need a soup therapy!
Wink~ wink~ Alas de America, you know what I'm talking about!
author: N. C.

description:
I hardly ever give five stars, but this is the best pho place in my book. My friends and I always go here whenever we're near Chinatown. We always order pho and we always come back for more. The soup is reallly goood. No doubt about that. The pho is just so good and the aroma is so enticing. The service is great here, nokidding. Everything in here is just super delicious. Even though, the management changes every few months, the food is good and the service is still the best ever, it really doesn't matter! The prices are actually very cheap and service is very quick! One time they forgot a meal in my friend's bowl, and they went back inside to get it and give it to us, which really
surprised us. GREAT SERVICE.

NOTE: came here recently and found hair in the pho.
06242008: They raised the prices and changed some of the recipes and guesswhat?! New management, yet again.
author: Jenny L.

description: I go here all the time and never order anything other than Beef Pho and Spring rolls. Why not switch it up you ask? Because, in my opinion, this place has the tastiest Pho I've ever put into my mouth. I may be a little white girl but I've had alot of Pho. Trust me.. try the Pho.. you'll never eat anything else there again either.
author: Sarah W.

description: Golden Flower is my backup viet joint for when I don't feel like waiting for Golden Star.  The pho is good enough to hit the spot and there's usually no wait.
author: Michelle T.

description: In, out, warm, satisfying, cheap, full. Exactly what I needed in a hot bowl of rare beef pho on a rainy afternoon.  Broth was slightly oversweet, but no complaints, got exactly what I came/paid for.
author: Talia R.

description: I'm not holding back. I *heart* you Golden Flower Vietnamese Restaurant. I *heart* your pho, especially the #8 and #10 which are flank steak with all of the noodles in their fresh, handmade goodness. I *heart* being allowed to choose how much basil and jalapeno that goes into your huge brothy bowl of savoriness. I *heart* you, I *heart* you!
author: Jim B.

description:
Pho review:

I went here with a group of 4 and we all ordered pho, and split an order of egg rolls, or more accurately cha gio.  The cha gio came out after the pho, which wasn't really cool because cha gio is an appetizer, and it ended up being the last thing we ate, cause who wants to eat cold-ass cha gio while you are pounding piping hot pho broth?

However, the egg rolls were tasty, fried well, and served with some rice vermicelli, crushed peanuts, and lettuce, which was nice to look at, but lacking since there wasn't enough of the extras to actually wrap each egg roll.

We all ordered small bowls of pho, and I noticed later that everyone else in the restaurant over the age of 8, ordered large bowls.  Maybe it was the lack of space in the small bowls, but I found my pho visually lacking something.  They did forget to put green onions in my broth, and what I had in front of me looked like a glorified bowl of instant pho that I make at home.  And glorified is actually being kind...it was a dead-ringer for packaged noodles with meat.

But to my surprise, the pho was actually pretty good.  The broth was aromatic and tasted like good pho broth should.  The noodles were cooked right and not too soft.

However, when we get to the meat, my last problem I had with my pho appears, and that was that the rare steak slices were sliced too thick yet still somehow overcooked.  That's actually pretty hard to do.

If i lived in the neighborhood, I'd give it a few more chances, but I'd be surprised if the problems I experienced here were an anomaly.
author: Tony L.

description:
This place is insanely cheap. The noodles are good. I order the small #3 every time. If I'm feeling really fancy, I'll order the spring rolls too. The food is good, not the best but fast, cheap and good. The downers are that they don't give you any water when you sit down. Also,  i cant help but feel like I'm being watched by an evil eye scolding and saying "eat faster" or "white people make such a mess"

Side note... There is the crazy old lady who collects cans in the area and stops at the window and glares at. She freaked my out the first time i caught her glance at the peopel inside. But now, I like to call her "grandma"
author: Dustin H.

description: I stumbled upon this place last week while working up an appetite taking photos in chinatown.  It was a cold overcast day and I wanted something warm and comforting and this place delivered the most giant bowl of really yummy pho.  Great service, cozy atmosphere and great food that's inexpensive.  I've been back since and plan to go back regularly cuz its close to my hood and the food is great.
author: Beth A.

description: Came back here this evening after not having come for a long time. This place was my first exposure to Vietnamese pho. Seems like the people running this place are now different. The noodle soup was good, but I have to give a lower star rating because one lady in particular was so unfriendly.
author: H K.

description:
Yummy yummy in my belly. Right now I am so full of clean, delicious, beef pho broth, noodles, and imperial rolls that my fingers are swaggering with delight as I write. Great place for quick great soul warming food.
And happy, friendly service..... This is the kind of place that if you leave your hat there and come back 2 weeks later the owner will remember you and give your hat back, even if you didn't remember you left it there and thought you left it in a cab at 3am on your way home from a big night out (true story).
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
I love their fish ball soup. Cheap, hot, filling.
I steer clear of the chicken dishes, not their specialty.
author: Katie h.

description: This is old school Pho is huge bowls. I like how they bring the chicken and pork separate from the noodle soup. It allows the flavors from the grill on the meat to get into the soup. One day I may try a noodle dish, but Pho is one of the best comfort foods in winter. It will have to wait until spring. Another case of needing half stars. I'd like to give this place a 4.5.
author: Gary W.

description:
Been here a few times and have yet to have anything bad about it.  Good food, cheap, maybe not a flavor packed as it could be but did I mention it was cheap as well.

The only thing that keeps it from getting five is the shrimp on sugar cane, which is not bad but could have been larger and not quite as greasy.

The rice plates are good but stick to the pho for the best experience.
author: Brian K.

description:
Vibrant atmosphere
High-traffic lunch-hour rush(es)
Crispy, flavoured rolls
author: Scott S.

description: Had a some Pho here and it was good! It was $5.75 for the small bowl of steak Pho. It was enough for dinner, and I was hungry, I will go back for a cheap, warm, and tasty dinner.
author: Spoke K.

description: This place saved us from walking around Chinatown trying to figure out where to eat and ducking the aggressive hawkers trying to get you into their chinese restaurant. It was a good choice. The pho with chicken was amazing. The broth was perfect, not greasy at all. My wife had the spring rolls and really enjoyed them. The price was reasonable and the service was very good. Of course, hot tea comes with every meal. Overall a great find.
author: Kyle S.

description: Went to Chinatown in search of good pho, and Golden Flower delivered. I ordered their "everything" pho: beef balls, tendon, tripe, brisket, the works. The broth was a little sweeter than I'm used to, but not too salty (pretty good overall). All the meats were cooked through to softness; I've had some places serve me chewy tendon which is a real turnoff. Fortunately not a problem here! Pretty decent lunch, came to around $9 for lunch after tip and taxes.
author: Andrew W.

description: MMMMM so good! The Pho and sweet and sour chicken are the best items on the menu! It's a small place but it's worth going into.
author: Samantha W.

description: I think i have eaten the most authentic vietnamese here, haven't been to the far east naturally. I really miss this place, for a picky eater like me, it is hard to forget the taste of food in this place.  sesame chicken was my favorite. with black and white sesame seeds and as Smokey aroma. Getting hungry thinking about it.
author: Sophie M.

description: I'm addicted to this place. This week I came here 3 times, and before that I usually make my rounds here twice a week. I have to warn you though, this isn't a pretty place. It's pretty grungy looking and it's def no place to bring someone on a first date. That said, it has really great pho!!! I thought I had found good pho places in the past, but I sometimes dream of coming here just because of the delicious broth. "#4, large please!"
author: Simon L.

description:
i have to give golden flower five stars because i had my first taste of vietnamese food EVER there, almost 5 years ago.  see, i'd moved here from michigan, and though i was a big pig even then, i had never tasted vietnamese food.  not much of that cuisine in mid-michigan.  and i was freakin' excited to taste some unfamiliar cuisine.  so, while on a jaunt to chinatown, i dropped in at golden flower and have been hooked ever since.  on pho, that is.

i have visited golden flower many times since, and, now being well-versed in the pho and bun that san francisco has to offer (going to school in the tenderloin, i eat a lot of pho and bun), i can safely say that they make a very fine bowl of pho there indeed.  i particularly enjoy the rare beef and tendon pho, and i always find the broth to be especially flavorful at golden flower.

you get plenty of bang for your buck at golden flower - under $5 for a big fat bowl of pho that you probably won't be able to finish.  meaning, a fair quantity of noodles left in the bowl after you've sucked down all that tasty broth.  mmm, tasty broth.

i've also greatly enjoyed their fresh spring rolls, as well as their delicious lemon grass shrimp.  i have noticed that their imperial rolls look a bit overcooked.  but i go there for their pho.  and it is some damn fine pho...
author: genevieve g.

description: The pho is AWFUL here.... don't get it. Save yourself. Gross. I guess if you were to come here, get the bun bo hue. I came here with a friend I haven't seen in a while, and it ruined our entire reunion vibe. Our outing was sadly cut short due to this. It is very empty on weekday nights after work.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Typical Vietnamese restaurant - I liked the vegetarian imperial / spring rolls with cold rice noodles. The vegetables were fresh and crisp, portion size was big. Staff was friendly, service was quick. A great spot for a simple yet delicious lunch under $8.
author: Shweta V.

description:
The pho was their specialty, not so much the other warm food.  The cold noodles without soup, with grilled meat and vegetables were good.  

This place used to have the best pho I'd ever had in my life.  Then the old man got more elderly, and sick, and eventually he and his wife sold it to her cousin.  I recognized the cousin from when I went into Mayflower on Ocean once where there was pho advertised with the American diner food; it was barely pho.  (The cousin's sister now runs Mayflower.)

How can they be from the same general family?  It seems like she should have been able to learn from him.  Her pho improved from Mayflower, but the restaurant sank.  The business really dropped and then picked up some and maybe dropped.  If I'd never had old man pho, then it would be acceptable, but once you have the best you can't go back.  Still we went back sometimes.

Then...

The last time we were there the food tasted like mothballs.  Why they are in a restaurant, I don' t know.  The person I was with didn't it notice as much until we asked for a container for the leftovers.  It reeked of mothballs.  

The worse thing that used to happen was that they forgot the meatballs several times when I got take out.  And there was the mass beef recall a while ago that the pho places couldn't participate in because their raw meat was all served.  But we never got sick there.

We are so incredibly sad that we'll probably never get that kind of pho again.  It probably died with the old man, if that's what happened.  It's almost hopeless to try.  We've given up expecting to find great pho again, just hoping to find something passable.

At one point, the old man's son ran Evergreen on Harrison.  I'd like to see what it's like if it's still there, although it's more of fusion of Vietnamese and Thai.  But even on the days the old man wasn't there the pho wasn't  as good, so it might never be the same.

Granted this place has scary looking prep areas and and scary looking bathroom, but it was okay when the food was still great.  

Cash only.
author: e g.

description: Stick to the straight Vietnamese specialties, and it's good.  (Skip what sounds like a standard rice plate from a Chinese restaurant.  It's the Vietnamese standards that shine.)
author: Laurel B.

description:
I'm not sure how many times this place has changed hands
Can't really judge the service, since all you ever really need them is to take down your order and give you the check, which they seem quite attentive 
Depending on what you order, the wait time obviously varies. 
Pho comes super fast and rice plates take a while.
I usually come here for the rice plates, which is approx. $7-$8.  The portions are HUGE, and unlike other places, you don't get complimentary soup, but who cares? 
The imperial rolls are definitely a hit spot, and the pho soup is definitely better than a lot of other places.
author: Emily L.

description: Pho-tastic! I've eaten here 3 nights in a row. Its a great place to call up and grab dinner on your way home from the office. The rice plates are kind of a dissapointment in terms of size, but the Pho is the bees knees. The imperial rolls are tasty but i much prefer the chicken summer roll with peanut sauce. Yum-o. There is a rumbly in my tumbly just thinking about it.
author: Stacy T.

description: I love this place. Whenever I go to Chinatown by myself, it's the only place I ever go to for lunch or dinner. You walk in and it doesn't seem roomy at all but it's not so bad. The lighting isn't the best during the day time but we all know how San Francisco skies can be. I have a pho addiction, and unafraid to admit it. This place always satisfied me. I also started the proposal for my current company and project there, a very small and brief meeting and announcement, with a few folks. I personally just go for the dac biet bowl and the small bowls down the front page. But every now and then I go for the egg rolls and shrimp on a stick and what not. Overall a great place, but not a place where you take a date... believe me, I tried. Hahaha.
author: Ryan R.

description: Casual and inexpensive Vietnamese restaurant in the Chinatown area with great-tasting, fresh food, and a lot of vegetarian options (about 15-20 items on their menu are vegetarian).  This place is worth the 8 block walk from my office, and I usually go here for lunch when it's not too busy at work.
author: Dinesh M.

description: Their pork chop rice is really good here! It is a lot for about $5. Also their chicken is really good also, I love the spices, or may be it is just msg?
author: Janet Z.

description: I have to add Golden Flower to the top 3 Vietnamese establishments I've visited. Its right up there with Vietnam, and Little Vietnam Cafe. Started out with the Imperial Rolls, crunchy and good. Had the #34 which was great: Two different kinds of pork (shredded noodle style and bbq), bean sprouts, carrots, mint, and noodles. Dump some of the sweet and sour sauce on top and you are good to go. Washed it all down with a sugary lemonade. Also took a sip of the Salty Lemonade, but a sip was enough...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Pho was cheap and pretty delicious, but service is rude. The waitress seated us at a table with a stranger, then pointedly hinted that we should pay and leave as it was getting crowded. I'd say the food isn't good enough to tempt me back here.
author: Angela X.

description: My favorite pho in the city -- not a lot of msg, great broth, extremely tasty imperial rolls.  I always get the larger bowl (which is too large, but the small is just a tad too small).
author: Mitzi C.

description:
i'm so full... i've got a giant bowl of pho noodles expanding in my stomach... 

so generally, most times i go to a new vietnamese restaurant, i'll order the #1. which, more often than not, means i just ordered the extra large pho with everything. the extra large bowl of noodles and broth i got today was more filling than usual. but it was quite tasty. the noodles were a good consistency - not too mushy or soft. the broth was good, but i'm not sure how i feel about it yet. it tasted a little different than at other pho places i've eaten at... the imperial rolls were great. 

best thing about it is i spent less than 10 bucks for a lot of good food and some serious food coma...
author: Steven L.

description: The Pho is super-savory. Chewy Noodles, hot and pungent broth and the hugest portion of meat that you could ask for along with it. I order the #21 more often than not, though their vermicelli bowls are totally out of control as well, as is basically every dish I've tried. This place is just your typical Chinatown pot-o-gold. Pretty dirty, small, poorly lit, kinda abrupt staff, and some of the best flippin soup you can get your sweaty little hands on in San Francisco. Seriously, eat here.
author: Eryn S.

description:
This place has great veggie friendly and healthy pho.  Since San Francisco is usually freezing, I often crave something warm yet filling - and this place has it!  The place is casual and really cheap so it is a great place to grab a quick weekday dinner.  It looks like a pretty standard Asian restaurant inside - not too decorated - but it is clean and simple which is nice to see. 

I've actually only tried their pho but you can request a vegetarian version which actually has vegetarian broth, and tons of vegetables and tofu. I requested some basil leaves on the side and they were very accommodating and brought out some right away.  To really enjoy the large soup bowl make sure you use all the fix-ins, especially the Sriracha hot sauce and the brown sauce (just a little though). 

Definitely recommend this place if you want some simple, yet delicious food.  I guarantee you will start craving it!
author: Sheena G.

description: This is my all time favorite Vietnamese Pho and catfish clay pot place.  The owner is from somewhere near Central Vietnam so the Pho broth is very similar to how my mom makes it (I'm from Hue), perfect to my taste!  As for the fish clay pot, it's cooked perfectly to our taste (99% of the time).  I say 99% because one time they either forgot to put suger or just didn't put enough and it was so salty, only ONE time.  This is why I gave them a 4 star (I would give 4 1/2 if I could) instead of 5.  Have to rate honestly.  Can't give perfect score if the restaurant makes mistakes, right?  Anyway, my husband and I have been back to this place many, many times.  We even bring friends and family members everytime they come to visit us and they all enjoyed the food there.  If you order the clay pot, just make sure to tell them to cook it extra long so that the sauce is caramalized...yum...yum.  The hot and sour shrimp or fish soup compliments the clay pot very well.....I highly recommend these dishes.  The service is excellent everytime we come here.
author: Sue N.

description: Yummy yummy pho. Been here twice so far and both times, Golden Flower has been able to satisfy my pho craving.  Roommate and I both got large orders of pho (way too much food... I'm going to stick to the small size in the future) and split a plate of the fried springrolls and total came out to about $17 after tax. Not too bad for all the food.
author: Christy H.

description:
best pho broth in town.
best imperial rolls with bbq pork on bun in town.

i mean, seriously, the only reason why you'd go anywhere else for vietnamese cuisine staples is because it's easier to find parking.

BTW, if you want water, you gotta ask for it.
author: dj z.

description: 5 stars for bomb ass 5 spice chicken!!!!!!!!!!!! and the pho is pretty good too! Man I have been going to chinatown for about 17 years now and have never eaten here til a few days ago! I LOVE this place! New favorite Pho joint! Better than Daly City places to me. =)
author: David Y.

description: I've been going to this chinatown gem for 15 years when I found it by happenstance on a cross-country trip with my best friend from childhood. Let's just say if you love soup, hot soup, and BIG bowls of soup, this is the place in SF. I learned to eat their Hiu tu tom cua (spelling? - seafood fish ball soup) by watching the native Vietnamese folks in the restaurant. Spoon in one hand, chopsticks in the other. Don't forget to mix in the fresh basil and careful on the fresh jalipeno! If you're in the neighborhood and want a hearty lunch on a cold SF day, definitely drop in. This is one hole-in-the-wall worth visiting!
author: Edward W.

description: This place is passable, but not very good.  The safest thing to get are the dry noodle plates with meat or egg rolls (bun), which aren't too bad.  The pho is pretty gross, and the other entrees can be pretty sketchy.
author: Jon N.

description: My favorite Vietnamese! Wish they had the sandwiches, but they have just about everything else. Yummm
author: Christina S.

description: Golden Flower is not about ambiance or service - just the food.  It's a great hole-in-the-wall restuarant for authentic, fresh, Vietnamese food... lots of veggie varieties.  They get quite the lunch crowd, so go before noon or after 1:30 to get seated quickly.
author: seema s.

description: This place is good for the Vietnamese purist who likes their pho with tripe and other stuff not found on Americanized menus.  They have a long list of dishes which are basically variations on the same things with different choices of meat.  I like the fish ball pho.  You can also get some cool drinks here, like lemonade which has a lot of sugar in it.  I saw someone drinking a milk soda which looked good.
author: apple r.

description: I never thought I'd say this about pho, but they gave me too much.  Broth, that is... slightly bland, "brown"-flavored broth with a sad clump of noodles lurking at the bottom, with a few equally sad beef balls floating forlornly.  I only went here because New Saigon was closed, I swear to Gawd.
author: Laura Y.

description:
Cheap.

Clean.

Good Service/ Polite/ Quick
I might be biased because I've become a regular take-out customer there now so they know me and ask how I've been

I find myself dialing that saved number "mmm chicken" every two weeks for their Five Spice Chicken. It's delish

Oh and their pho ain't bad either
author: Lorrie C.

description: Worse bowl of Pho I have ever tasted. The broth is very tasteless and the noodle is the worse I have seen. Needless to say, I won't be coming back.
author: Henry N.

description: I would have to say this is one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in Chinatown.  Their bun bo hue is not bad but the fresh pork spring roll and imperial roll is pretty good.  The manager/cashier tends to yell at the workers though.
author: Mary L.

description: Hey now, that's good pho! A very savory broth and decent ingredients at a nice price. Feels less cafeteria-like inside than other spots in the hood, reminds me of some mom and pop shops I used to frequent back home.  I also like the fact that the iced coffee isn't jacked up to $2.50 a cup yet. A solid lunch option.
author: Tom H.

description: Worth the work lunchtime journey to Chinatown for pho!  This is the real stuff and great value too.
author: Debbie Y.

description: One of the best pho's around. I've only had the rare beef pho - it's so good and satisfying I've never had to try anything else. A bowl of pho will set you back $5 - a pretty cheap lunch or diner. The imperial rolls are also very good crunchy, fresh and full of flavor. One of the best Vietnamese places I've been to so far...
author: Russ C.

description: I give it 3 stars - food is good and consistent. bowls of pho are served steaming hot and always plenty - i usually have a hard time finishing. come here often with coworkers and usually find myself seated next to a stranger, but that's okay, we are all united by the pho.
author: laura f.

description: this pho place used to be good. now it's gone down the drain. the soup base is not as good as it used to be and you get less noodles.
author: Ann L.

description: The pho wasn't bad, but I've had better. The meatballs tasted a little undercooked. And I only got one piece of tendon in mine.. I also ordered egg rolls, which were yummy (: BUT, they didn't even notice that they forgot my sauce, haha. The service was great, they were really friendly. It was kinda sorta awkward because the whole time we were eating, they sat there and stared at me and my family the whole time. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'll be going there again.
author: Kaylyna M.

description: The food is pretty good. Lunch can be a little crowded. It's pretty cheap. The service can be a little flaky, but as long as the food is good, right? I got the spring rolls. The sauce for the spring rolls was yummy!
author: Pika C.

description: If you don't compare this place to the other vietnamese restaurant, then I would say the food is good.  For experience vietnamese food eater, I think there is better choices out there.  The pho broth is not flavorful enough and noodles aren't "silky" soft.  Portions aren't huge like it should be for a #1 extra large combination beef pho.  Service was also a liitle bit on the down side cuz they brought out the noodles before the bean sprout and I gotta ask them two times.  By the time the bean sprout comes, my soup wasn't hot enough to really soften them.
author: Heidi F.

description: I was introduced to this place by the ex-cultural attaché of French embassy in SF, who lived long time in Vietnam. I like food there very much. Great for lunch and fast dinner.
author: Vera S.

description: Best Pho in Chinatown (but haven't tried Golden Star, so this opinion may change), and also very good Bun (noodles) -- get the bun cha yau (noodles with fried spring rolls; yum!). Inexpensive, with decent service; not overly friendly, just businesslike, as with most places in Chinatown.
author: Bruce C.

description: The Pho here is pretty tasty and good.  It's cash only but they accommodate for big groups fairly well.
author: Buddy R.

description:
i've been here since i was three years old and i still come here whenever i get the chance to. i'm pretty upset that they changed owners to their cousin because the placej ust doesnt feel the same anymore. it looks different compared to hwo they use to look and their cousin is a mean ass bitch! shes pretty fucked up to her workers from what iv'e seen from all the yelling and hand motions. 

besides that, i've loved this place for a long time. the old man and his wife that use to work there was so damn nice and always said hi to me. i know for sure he remembered me because he use to have a place on irving st. too but that didnt last long. this will always be one of my favorite restaurants hands down despite the owner change.
author: Kenny L.

description:
my friend and i ordered two #1s. 
since it was a large bowl, we expected it to have more ingredients. 
sadly, this was not the case. 

we got something like two beef balls, *thinly* cut beef tripe, super well-done streak that was supposed to be rare in the first place, and basically little other scraps of various parts of cow. Not as much beef as i would have liked, and TOO MUCH NOODLE. come on man. It's called BEEF NOODLE. where's the beef? we're in a recession and all but still. we're talking Chinatown, where the place is cheap, and apparently so are the ingredients. 

ok service. nothing special.
author: john d.

description: Fairly decent lunch pho place. I had the usual pho with beef. Broth was decent, no comparison to Pho Tau Bay or Pho Kim Long in San Jose. I didn't find the complex depth of flavors I found in the San Jose pho noodle houses. Service was fast, I will definitely be returning here until I find better pho in the city.
author: Joon L.

description: Yes I miss Golden Flower... I used to live in North Beach, every weekend I would go there for lunch. I know the owner, he used to have another restaurant in North Bay I . I love the "cat fish" really the best! and the beef noodle is good also... I moved away and don't go there much anymore, really miss it. I would highly recommend the cat fish... and of course the ice coffee.... so good. The food always makes me smile. The place is not high end, it's really just  the "family and friends" place for a good meal.
author: Caroline C.

description: This morning I had the craving for something barbecued.  It was 11 a.m. and I was already hungry for lunch so my friend Diane and I left the office before noon and we walked to Chinatown.  We stepped inside to the modest, but very busy dining room of Golden Flower.  I scanned their menu and found what I thought might my satisfy my craving- # 51, Flame Broiled Pork Chops over rice (I also asked for a fried egg).  Not bad-not bad at all!  Actually, I thought it was terrific!  Their menu is extensive and shows the promise of a long and happy lunch relationship.  One other thing- this place is really inexpensive.
author: Denny L.

description: Wonderful Pho. Well worth the trip. Also, delicious spring rolls, fine beef salad, great chicken pho.
author: Graham M.

description: Excellent Pho with very flavourful broth. Not too fancy. Very busy at lunch.
author: Jim P.

description:
you know you're heart/physically sick to heart when you don't have much energy to write or the energy to get up and pee this morning.

***

4.5

extremely cheap & tasty. very homey.

ever thought of having pho for breakfast? and don't you ferget to order cha gio.  $5 each way = me happy.

service = 5stars as well

i don't got the energy to write much, but i have to say, i'll definitely come back.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Damn PHO! I walked in here looking for a Vietnamese sandwich. You see it's one of my culinary obsessions. This city is so wonderful in that sense that you can go on the hunt for a: burrito, dim sum, Vietnamese sandwich and  other ethnic fast foods and practically never run out of places to go. I think Pho is up there too. There are probably hundreds of places to go to for Pho in this city. So seeing that they didn't sandwiches I walked out but before I could leave the door I saw somebody eating some Pho. I said "damn pho!" that pho looks good! So I sat down and decided to have a bowl. I did like that you can get a small size and a big size. Having gotten stoned the night before and having gorged myself on everything in my fridge, I decided that the smaller bowl would be best. I have had quite a few pho's in my time, and I have to say that this was some of the best broth I have had. Fantastico! So good. The ambiance is...well...its...Chinatown; what do you expect?! But that's not why you should come here. The pho was great and I would go just for that. I can only assume the other stuff on the menu is good to. Stay tuned...I will be back here.
author: Steve H.

description: definitely nothing special.  i hadn't heard about it before but they had a bunch of reviews taped on their front window, so i thought it'd be decent.  not really.  i ordered my usual of vermicelli with imperial rolls.  only half the bowl had noodles, which i guess is OK portion-wise for me, but it's much less than most other places offer.  there are at least a couple other better places in the area for the same menu.
author: spiff e.

description: This place rocks! clean, cheap, and great food. I like #40, broiled beef over noodles with imperial rolls.
author: Ryan O.

description: Clean, economical and wowza - food is terrific.  Soups are delicious. This place looks like a dive from the outside - but it's squeaky clean and delish on the inside. Prices were wonderful.  Service was super fast.
author: kiyo r.

description: awww i like this lil spot. the service is so friendly, and they speak pretty good english. i ordered a large pho no meat (weird, i know) and i got this huuuuuge bowl full of noodles. i was a lil hesitant because there wasn't a ton of color to the broth, but the flavor was still pretty good, the noodles could've been a lil more.....rubber-band-like? softer, chewier? lol but all in all i liked this place, very home-y feeling.
author: Kimberly P.

description: i came here a few times with my girls to eat. i came here for lunch/dinner. this place is kinna small, but it has the warm coozy feeling when you're inside eating, feels like home. i gotta admit their pho is pretty good! parking anywhere in ctown is a pain in the ass unless you're lucky, but you still gotta pay for meter. lol
author: Valerie N.

description: the soup base is good. maybe because its overloaded with msg. hmm! well fyi its pretty good but there cleanliness is a downfall. i found gnats in my soup or veg a couple of times. my uncle does plumbing work in the kitchen and he said its infested with RATS yes i said it infested with RATS.
author: Tasha L.

description: my favorite pho restaurant in all San Francisco!
author: Valentina V.

description: pretty damn good pho. i had veggies and tofu with beef broth. the best tasting soup i've had in a long time. Service was poor but it was good enough. the deep fried rolls were good too.
author: rukshan b.

description: Very randomly, j and I were wandering around chinatown on a sunday. The place we wanted to eat wasn't serving what we wanted right then, so we just walked into this place. I saw the article on the front saying how pho is their best thing here, and I almost got pho... but I'm just sooo not a soup person at all. J does like it sometimes, but he still didn't get pho. He got a seafood combo that comes with rice noodles. His looked pretty good... sauce over the noodles, and a medium sized meal. He said it seemed like there was a lot of junk seafood like imitation crab in there. But it was ok. I had lemongrass pork and I substituted rice noodles for the rice (even though the waiter was SHOCKED and couldn't believe, for some reason, that I wanted this... is it really so weird??). I had almost gotten something with shredded pork, but he told me it was pork skin, rightly assuming I didn't want that. So that was nice of the waiter. My food was SMALL. A tiny bit of meal only taking half of the tiny plate. The other half was the noodles. The noodles were good. The pork was ok. Besides the reccomending that I don't want shredded pork, our service was pretty rude. Not overtly, but just an air of rudeness. Exasperated when we took too long to order. Ignoring us the whole meal. Talking loudly to each other when we wanted our check, instead of coming to bring it to us. Stuff like that. So, not too friendly, just ok food, small portions were all minuses... plusses were that we were seated right away (plenty of empty tables) and the number one plus was the PRICE. It was so cheap - $16 for two people. So, you get what you pay for. We were both very hungry after, so we went home and made cookies. PS cash only
author: Merredith L.

description: I love the service here. The waitress was friendly, well-mannered, and always had on a smile. The pho, which is the only thing I ever ordered there, was plentiful and had lots of the meat and stuff. The place is kind of small, but has that nice atmosphere. The restaurant is very clean. Overall, I like this place and I'd go again.
author: Tony L.

description: This restaurant offers large portions of good food for a great price.  It's the type of Chinatown restaurant with the cheesy glass tabletops and paper placemats.  But, it offers large bowls of pho for $6.   The selection is ok, but they have a great broth.  It's not too heavy, but it's still super flavorful.  Their rice platters are pretty generous as well.  You'll be seated by a gesture from a the formidable looking woman in the back of the room and you'll most likely get your food within 10 minutes.  Not bad at all.
author: Raz R.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. Love the fact that they accept credit card in Chinatown. The Pho is very good there. Service is kinda ok. author: Jon J.

description: if you've ever wondered if pho could kick ass, this is where it does.  i had the pho with tendon, tripe and raw beef (i was feeling adventurous) and it was damn good.  the imperial rolls with the peanut sauce were awesome too.  if you're poor but want a lot of food this is the place.  you won't get a lot of ambiance here but they do have some cool instruments on the walls.  we asked the guy there about one of the violin-like instruments and he wasn't ashamed to admit that he knew absolutely nothing about it.  at least he was honest. i don't like bullshiters.
